{{See also|Forensic facial reconstruction}} {{None}} {{expert needed|date=January 2018}} {{More citations needed|date=August 2011}} {{ForensicScience|criminal}}
'''Forensic art''' is any [[art]] used in [[Law enforcement agency|law enforcement]] or [[legal process|legal proceedings]]. Forensic art is used to assist law enforcement with the visual aspects of a case, often using witness descriptions and video footage.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://forensicfaces.weebly.com/what-is-forensic-art.html|title=What is Forensic Art? - Forensic Faces Institute|website=forensicfaces.weebly.com|access-date=2017-11-06}}</ref>
It is a highly specialised field that covers a wide range of artistic skills, such as [[Facial composite|composite drawing]], crime scene sketching, [[image modification]] and identification, courtroom drawings, demonstrative evidence, and postmortem and facial approximation aids. It is rare for a forensic artist to specialise in more than one of these skills.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theiai.org/disciplines/art/history.php|title=History of the I.A.I. Forensic Art Discipline|website=www.theiai.org}}</ref> The following is a breakdown of different skills and what they involve: * <u>'''Composite Drawing:'''</u> the main objective is to help investigators generate leads based on physical descriptions. This is usually drawn by hand; an artist who is trained in interviewing victims and witnesses uses the information provided to draw what is described.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.forensicmag.com/article/2004/12/forensic-art-defined-and-explained|title=Forensic Art Defined and Explained|date=2004-12-01|work=Forensic Magazine|access-date=2017-11-06}}</ref> Composite art produces a single, graphic image that is designed to be a likeness or similarity of the individual.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.crimesceneinvestigatoredu.org/forensic-artist/|title=Forensic Artist Job Description, Education Requirements and Salary Expectations|website=www.crimesceneinvestigatoredu.org|language=en-US|access-date=2018-01-29}}</ref> * '''<u>Image Modification:</u>''' this is used to change and enhance a photograph in order to help an investigator and/or trial attorney. Examples of this include age progression/regression (see below),<ref name="p1698608879">https://search.proquest.com/docview/1698608879</ref> and the clarifying of images, such as from CCTV footage, to identify an individual.<ref name=":0" /> * '''<u>Image Identification:</u>''' this is the recording a person's distinguishing features for future reference. Investigators can use this tool to identify suspects who attempts to change their appearance to evade capture, as well as in the study of cold cases in which individuals may have changed their appearance since the event.<ref name="p1698608879" /> * '''<u>Crime Scene Sketching:</u>''' the drawing of a crime scene; in the sketch, an investigator includes measurements and dimensions to aid in displaying the layout of the scene. This helps support the information shown in photographs of the scene.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.evidencemagazine.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=184|title=Evidence Technology Magazine – Documenting the Crime Scene|last=MAYO|first=KRISTI|website=www.evidencemagazine.com|access-date=2017-11-06}}</ref> * '''<u>Demonstrative Evidence:</u>''' any visible, physical evidence used in legal proceedings. These are used to demonstrate aspects of the case, reconstruct an event, and illustrate what happened. There are two categories of demonstrative evidence; court displays and investigative aids.<ref name="p1698608879" /> * '''<u>Postmortem Drawing:</u>''' when an artist either looks at a deceased person's photograph or their remains to help identify who the person is and what they looked like prior to their death. This helps most in cases where the body is too damaged by an accident or decomposition.<ref name="p1698608879" /><ref name=":0" /> * '''<u>Age Progression/Regression</u>''': useful to determine what a person's appeearance before or after a period of time. This is most commonly used in missing persons cases or during cold cases when investigators need an idea of what an individual looked like years prior to or following the investigation. * '''<u>Forensic Sculpture</u>''': this is used to create three-dimensional models, usually using the skull of the victims. Other features are added such as fake eyes and wigs to add realism. This process can also inform the investigators of certain characteristics of the victim - such as age, race, and gender - through a detailed knowledge of the intricacies of skeletal structure and other corresponding features such as dental records. It is later photograph and used like postmortem and composite drawings. However, because forensic sculpture relies heavily on assumptions made by the artist, it is not considered a legally recognised technique for positive identification, and is thus used in an advisory capacity only.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Helmer et al. Assessment of the Reliability of Facial Reconstruction|last=|first=|publisher=|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=}}</ref> * <u>'''Collaboration:'''</u> forensic artists, anthropologists and other professions are used to help determine the age, sex, and race of an identified skull.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://archives.fbi.gov/archives/about-us/lab/forensic-science-communications/fsc/jan2001/taister.htm|title=Book Review of Forensic Art and Illustration (by Taylor), by Taister (Forensic Science Communications, January 2001)|last=Taister|first=Karen T. Taylor, Taylor, Michael A. Taister,|work=FBI|access-date=2017-12-04|language=en-us}}</ref> Many forensic artists do the job as a collateral duty to their "regular" job in law enforcement, such as police officer, crime scene tech, etc. Such forensic artists perform their work while on a fixed salary and are not additionally compensated for artistic duties. There are few full-time forensic artist jobs available. Most full-time artists work in large cities, or in state or federal agencies. "Freelancing" in forensic art is a difficult career path, as ties to law enforcement are a necessary part of the job, and agencies have limited budgets to pay outside contractors.
The skill of '''facial approximation''' is closely associated and related to [[forensic anthropology]] in that an artist specializes in the reconstruction of the remains of a human body. Generally this discipline focuses on the human face for identification purposes. The forensic artist can create a facial approximation in a number of ways to include 2D ([[drawing]]s), 3D ([[sculpture]]s) and other methods using new computer technology. Forensic artists generally can add greater character and make their subjects come back to "life".
== Methods of Manual 3d construction == * Anthropometric was a method developed by [[Wilton M. Krogman]] in 1946 .<ref name="ebscohost.com">{{cite web|url=https://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=a9h&AN=110682508&site=ehost-livepose-methods.html|title=What is Anthropometric Measurement? - Tools, Purpose & Methods – Video & Lesson Transcript |website=study.com|access-date=2017-12-05}}</ref> * Facial muscles are recorded by a highly trained professional. This job is particularly tedious, which is why most do not use this method. * Computerized 3d forensic facial reconstruction- manual model clay techniques are used within this method. Computer systems vary, in that some computerized systems used 3D animation software to model the face onto the skull, while other systems use a virtual sculpture system with Haptic feedback<ref name="ebscohost.com" /> * Haptic Feedback- The ability to feel the surface of the skull during analysis and also provide important skeletal details for facial reconstruction such as muscle attachment strength, position of eye, position of malar tubercle etc.<ref name="ebscohost.com" />
== Face model creation == When creating a face model, the forensic artist looks at whether the person is masculine or feminine, as well as their skin tone, age, wrinkles, freckles, the shadow of the beard, and attractiveness. There are three segments that they examine: * Face shape: round, narrow, heart shape, high/low cheeks, high/low chin, double chin, the distance between lips and nose. * Eyes: round, upwards/downwards, the distance of eyeballs, eye color, thin/thick eyebrows, high/low arch brow, distance between both eyebrows, distance between eyebrows and eyes. * Hair: the 3D models have not been programmed to be used with hair, therefore, hair cannot be used the same way as facial attributes. A profile and frontal image of a person is used where 5 to 15 different key features of each hairstyle are selected. These different hairstyles features are from a database used by these professionals. The styles are put into the system where the algorithm automatically estimates the structure of the face. The system is also able to depict different shade of color.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=a9h&AN=23414201&site=ehost-live|title=EBSCOhost Login|website=search.ebscohost.com}}</ref>
== Becoming a Forensic Artist == To qualify for a professional certification for forensic arts - such as the Forensic Art Certification, which is provided through the [https://www.theiai.org/certifications/artist/index.php International Association for Identification] - applicants can focus on one or more of the three available categories of professional designation: composite imaging, facial reconstruction, and image enhancement/age progression,<ref name=":0" /> and must: * have at least 80 hours of IAI-approved forensic art training<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.crimesceneinvestigatoredu.org/forensic-artist/|title=Forensic Artist Job Description, Education Requirements and Salary Expectations|website=www.crimesceneinvestigatoredu.org|language=en-US|access-date=2017-12-05}}</ref> * have at least 40 hours of related workshops, lectures, and short program training * have at least 2 years of experience as forensic arts * provide at least 30 forensic art examples that include age progressions, composites, and reconstructions * have a portfolio that demonstrates their forensic art techniques (must include at least 10 forensic art images that were prepared for law enforcement investigation cases)<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.crimesceneinvestigatoredu.org/forensic-artist/|title=Forensic Artist Job Description, Education Requirements, and Salary Expectations|website=www.crimesceneinvestigatoredu.org|language=en-US|access-date=2017-12-04}}</ref>

Central High School of Needle Trades
Harlem Evening High School | alma_mater = [[Fashion Institute of Technology]]
New School of Social Research's Dramatic Workshop
[[Hood College]] | occupation = | years_active = | known_for = | spouse = {{marriage|Mischa Friedman|1956|1998|end=died}} | children = 2 }} '''Greta Zimmer Friedman''' (born '''Grete Zimmer'''; June 5, 1924 – September 8, 2016) was an Austrian-born American who was photographed being kissed by a stranger, a Navy [[sailor]], in the iconic ''[[V-J Day in Times Square]]'' photograph of 1945 by ''[[Life (magazine)|Life magazine]]'' photographer [[Alfred Eisenstaedt]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2016/sep/11/greta-zimmer-friedman-dies-kissed-sailor-world-war/|title=Greta Zimmer Friedman dies; kissed sailor in World War II iconic photo|last=|first=|date=September 11, 2016|website=The Washington Times|publisher=|access-date=2016-09-14}} Widely misattributed as being a photograph of a nurse, she was actually a dental assistant with a similar uniform. ==Early life and education== [[File:1939 Passport.jpg|thumb|1939 passport issued by the government of Austria for "Grete Sara Zimmer," the middle name added by national socialist decree]] She was born Grete Zimmer on June 5, 1924 to a Jewish family in [[Wiener Neustadt]], Austria.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/09/11/nyregion/greta-friedman-who-claimed-to-be-the-nurse-in-a-famous-v-j-day-photo-dies-at-92.html|title=Greta Friedman, Who Claimed to Be the Nurse in a Famous V-J Day Photo, Dies at 92|last=Rosenberg|first=Eli|date=September 10, 2016|work=|newspaper=The New York Times|issn=0362-4331|access-date=2016-09-12|via=}} At age 15, Zimmer emigrated from Nazi-controlled Austria in 1939 with her younger sisters Josefin (Fini) and Bella; as Americans, Josefin became Josephine (Jo), while Grete and Bella traded the last letter of each name to become Greta and Belle. The eldest Zimmer sister Lily emigrated to Palestine, took the name Tirza, and remained in Israel after fighting in the 1948 War of Independence. Their parents, Max and Ida, unable to leave Europe, died in concentration camps during the [[The Holocaust|Holocaust]].{{Cite web|url=https://nypost.com/2012/06/17/the-true-story-behind-the-iconic-v-j-day-sailor-and-nurse-smooch/|title=The true story behind the iconic V-J Day sailor and ‘nurse’ smooch|last=Callahan|first=Maureen|date=June 17, 2012|website=New York Post|publisher=|access-date=2016-09-15}} Zimmer attended Queens Vocational High School, the Central High School of Needle Trades and the Harlem Evening High School. Supporting herself as a dental assistant, she then took classes at the [[Fashion Institute of Technology]] (FIT) and studied costuming with the New School of Social Research's [[Dramatic Workshop]], led by [[Erwin Piscator]]. Later, while living in New York in the 1940s and 1950s, she variously worked in toy design and doll clothing, as well as early television with the [[Bil Baird]] puppets, and summer theater at the Camp [[Tamiment]] Playhouse. ==''V-J Day in Times Square''== On VJ Day, August 14, 1945, Friedman had left work at the dentists' office dressed in her uniform and was celebrating the end of World War II in [[Times Square]] when a stranger dressed in a Navy sailor's uniform grabbed her and kissed her. Photographer [[Alfred Eisenstaedt]], who was in Times Square documenting the celebration, captured the moment with his [[Leica Camera|Leica]]. The resulting photograph, ''[[V-J Day in Times Square]]'', was first published in ''[[Life (magazine)|Life]]'' magazine in 1945 with the caption, "In New York's Times Square a white-clad girl clutches her purse and skirt as an uninhibited sailor plants his lips squarely on hers".{{Cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/culture/news/greta-friedman-woman-in-times-square-kiss-photo-dead-at-92-w438994|title=Greta Friedman, Woman in Iconic Times Square Kiss Photo, Dead at 92|last=Kreps|first=Daniel|date=|website=Rolling Stone|publisher=|access-date=2016-09-15}} When Eisenstaedt took the photo, he failed to get any personal information from his subjects leaving their identities unknown for decades. In the ensuing years, many women claimed to be the woman in the photo. Friedman eventually saw the photo again the 1960s and instantly recognized herself. She wrote to ''Life'' magazine and provided additional photos to verify her identity. ''Life'' editors did not contact her until 1980 when, after researching and analysis, confirmed that Friedman was the woman in the photograph.{{cite web |last1=Lewis |first1=Danny |title=The Woman in the Iconic V-J Day Kiss Photo Died at 92, Here’s Her Story |url=https://www.smithsonianmag.com/smart-news/woman-iconic-v-j-photo-died-age-92-heres-her-story-180960435/ |website=Smithsonian.com |publisher=Smithsonianmag.com |accessdate=August 27, 2018 |date=September 14, 2016}} While ''V-J Day in Times Square'' went on to become an iconic photo that was generally viewed as a celebratory and romantic photograph, Friedman had mixed feelings about it. "It wasn’t my choice to be kissed," Friedman stated in a 2005 interview with the [[Library of Congress]].{{cite web|url=http://memory.loc.gov/diglib/vhp/story/loc.natlib.afc2001001.42863/transcript?ID=sr0001|title=Interview Transcript: Greta Zimmer Friedman: Veterans History Project (Library of Congress)|last=Redmond|first=Patricia|date=August 23, 2005|website=American Memory|accessdate=September 12, 2016}} "The guy just came over and grabbed!" she said, adding, "That man was very strong. I wasn’t kissing him. He was kissing me."{{cite web|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/new-york/famed-image-marking-v-j-day-sinister-shade-article-1.2774540|title=How a celebrated image marking V-J Day in Times Square has taken on a sinister shade|last=Martino|first=Andy|date=September 2, 2016|website=New York Daily News|accessdate=September 12, 2016}} "I did not see him approaching, and before I know it I was in this tight grip," Friedman told [[CBS News]] in 2012.{{cite web|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/greta-friedman-woman-kissed-in-iconic-v-j-day-photo-dead-at-92|title=Woman in V-J Day photo dead at 92|date=September 10, 2016|website=CBS News|accessdate=September 10, 2016}} ==Later years and death== In 1956 she married Dr. Mischa Friedman, a WWII veteran of the U.S. Army Air Corps and a scientific researcher for the Army at [[Fort Detrick]], moving to [[Frederick, Maryland]]. She attended [[Hood College]], studying oil painting, printing, sculpture, and watercolors, but did not graduate until 1981, the same year her two grown children Mara and Joshua also graduated college. Friedman worked for ten years at Hood restoring books.{{Cite web|url=http://memory.loc.gov/diglib/vhp/story/loc.natlib.afc2001001.42863/transcript?ID=sr0001|title=Interview Transcript: Greta Zimmer Friedman: Veterans History Project (Library of Congress|last=|first=|date=August 23, 2005|website=memory.loc.gov|publisher=|access-date=2016-09-15}} [[File:Niche at Arlington National Cemetery.png|thumb|Inurnment at Arlington National Cemetery]] Friedman died at age 92 on September 8, 2016, in [[Richmond, Virginia]]. She is inurned beside her husband at [[Arlington National Cemetery]].{{cite web|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/greta-zimmer-friedman-nurse-iconic-wwii-kissing-photo-dies-92-n646111|title=Greta Zimmer Friedman, 'Nurse' in Iconic WWII Kissing Photo, Dies at 92|last=Chuck|first=Elizabeth|last2=Calabrese|first2=Erin|date=September 10, 2016|website=NBC News|publisher=|access-date=2016-09-12}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==Further reading== * {{cite web|url=http://memory.loc.gov/diglib/vhp/story/loc.natlib.afc2001001.42863/transcript?ID=sr0001|title=Interview Notes|date=August 23, 2005|publisher=[[Library of Congress|LOC]]|series=American Folklife Center|first=Patricia|last=Redmond}} * Sulzgruber, Werner, Lebenslinien. Jüdische Familien und ihre Schicksale. Eine biografische Reise in die Vergangenheit von Wiener Neustadt. Berger, Wien / Horn 2013, {{ISBN|978-3-85028-557-5}}. [biographies of Jewish families from Wiener Neustadt, Austria, incl. a chapter about family Zimmer] * Verria, Lawrence, and Galdorisi, George. The Kissing Sailor: The Mystery Behind the Photo That Ended World War II. Naval Institute Press, May 15, 2012, {{ISBN|1612510787}}. {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Friedman, Greta Zimmer}} [[Category:1924 births]] [[Category:2016 deaths]] [[Category:Austrian emigrants to the United States]] [[Category:Austrian Jews]] [[Category:American people of Austrian-Jewish descent]] [[Category:Burials at Arlington National Cemetery]] [[Category:Fashion Institute of Technology alumni]] [[Category:Hood College alumni]] [[Category:Kissing]] [[Category:People from Frederick, Maryland]] [[Category:People from Wiener Neustadt]] [[Category:People notable for being the subject of a specific photograph]] [[Category:People with acquired American citizenship]]

{{Infobox artwork | image_file = PICASSO Le pigeon aux petits pois 1911.jpg | title = Le pigeon aux petits pois | alt = Le pigeon aux petits pois by Picasso | other_language_1 = English | other_title_1 = Pigeon with small Peas | artist = [[Pablo Picasso]] | year = {{Start date|1911}} | medium = Oil on canvas | height_metric = 65 | width_metric = 54 | height_imperial = | width_imperial = | metric_unit = cm | imperial_unit = in | museum = Missing after theft from [[Musée d'Art Moderne de la Ville de Paris]] in 2010
Possibly destroyed }} '''''Les pigeon aux petit pois''''' (''Pigeons with peas''){{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/10130840.stm |title=Five masterpieces stolen from Paris modern art museum |date=20 May 2010 |newspaper=[[BBC News Online]]}} is a 1911 painting by [[Pablo Picasso]].{{cite web |url=http://www.latimes.com/news/la-fg-paintings-stolen-pictures,0,4090079.photogallery |title=PHOTOS: Theft at Paris Museum of Modern Art |accessdate=20 May 2010 |date= 20 May 2010 |work=[[Los Angeles Times]] |publisher=[[Tribune Company]]}} It was one of five paintings stolen from the [[Musée d'Art Moderne de la Ville de Paris]] on 20 May 2010, which together are worth about €100 million ($123 million). The thief and his sponsor were found the following year, and the latter has declared that he was seized by panic after a police raid and a phone call by the police, and put the painting in a rubbish container. However, the police doubt that assertion.{{Citation|author=Nathaniel Herzberg|newspaper=Le Monde|date=2012-05-15|title=A la recherche du butin perdu}}{{cite web|url=http://newsfeed.time.com/2012/04/16/pilfered-paintings-five-famous-art-heists-through-history/slide/good-artists-borrow-great-artists-steal/|title='Art Heist of the Century' in Paris - Pilfered Paintings: Five Famous Art Heists Through History - TIME.com|work=TIME.com}} The copy of this painting is shown in James Bond's movie [[Spectre (2015 film)|''Spectre'']] at the wall in Oberhausers Moroccan lair.{{Cite news|url=http://www.jamesbondlifestyle.com/articles/closing-credits-spectre|title=Closing credits: SPECTRE|date=2016-05-05|work=Bond Lifestyle|access-date=2018-04-06|language=en}} ==See also== *[[List of famous stolen paintings]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{Pablo Picasso}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Pigeon aux petits pois}} [[Category:Paintings by Pablo Picasso]] [[Category:1911 paintings]] [[Category:Cubist paintings]] [[Category:Birds in art]] [[Category:Stolen works of art]] [[Category:Still life paintings]] {{20C-painting-stub}}

{{italic title}} {{Infobox film | name = Life, Animated | image = Life, Animated Official Poster.jpg | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Roger Ross Williams]] | based_on = ''Life, Animated: A Story of Sidekicks, Heroes, and Autism''
by [[Ron Suskind]] | producer = {{Plainlist| * [[Julie Goldman (producer)|Julie Goldman]] * [[Roger Ross Williams]] * Carolyn Hepburn * Christopher Clements }} | writer = [[Ron Suskind]] | starring = [[Jonathan Freeman (actor)|Jonathan Freeman]]
[[Gilbert Gottfried]]
Alan Rosenblatt
Owen Suskind
Ron Suskind | music = Dylan Stark
T. Griffin | cinematography = Tom Bergmann | editing = David Teague | studio = [[Motto Pictures]]
A&E IndieFilms
Roger Ross Williams Productions | distributor = [[The Orchard (company)|The Orchard]] | released = {{Film date|2016|7|01}} | runtime = 92 minutes | country = United States | language = English | budget = | gross = }} '''''Life, Animated''''' is a 2016 American documentary by director [[Roger Ross Williams]].{{cite news|title=Life, Animated – Roger Ross Williams|url=http://www.btlnews.com/awards/life-animated-roger-ross-williams/|last=Alexander Child|first=Doreen|date=January 8, 2017|accessdate= January 17, 2017| publisher= Below The Line}} It is co-produced by Williams with [[Julie Goldman (producer)|Julie Goldman]], Carolyn Hepburn and Christopher Clements. ''Life, Animated'' is based on journalist [[Ron Suskind]]'s 2014 book ''Life, Animated: A Story of Sidekicks, Heroes, and Autism'', which tells the story of his son, Owen Suskind who struggled with [[autism]] and learned how to communicate with the outside world through his love of [[Disney films]].{{cite web|title=Life, Animated review – a tremendous story of family love and Disney cartoons:This poignant documentary is about an autistic boy who learned how to understand the world and communicate with it through Disney character|url= https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/dec/08/life-animated-review-documentary-disney-owen-suskind-autism|last=Bradshaw|first=Peter |publisher=''The Guardian''|date=December 8, 2016|accessdate=January 17, 2017}} Upon its release, the film received rave reviews from critics and won numerous awards including the [[2017 Sundance Film Festival|Sundance Film Festival]] award for Best Direction and the Special Achievement [[Annie Award]]. It was also nominated for the [[Academy Award for Best Documentary Feature]] category at the [[89th Academy Awards]], but lost to ''[[O.J.: Made in America]]''.{{cite news|last1=Samuelson|first1=Kate|title=Here Are the 2017 Oscar Nominations|url=http://time.com/4635815/2017-oscars-nominations-list/|accessdate=January 24, 2017|work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|date=January 24, 2017}}{{cite news|url=http://www.oscars.org/news/15-documentary-features-advance-2016-oscar-race|title=15 Documentary Feature advance in 2016 Oscar Race|date=December 6, 2016|accessdate=January 15, 2017|publisher=Oscars.org}}{{cite news|title='Life, Animated' Documentary On Oscar Shortlist|url=http://www.wbur.org/hereandnow/2017/01/16/life-animated-oscars|date=January 16, 2017|accessdate=January 17, 2017| publisher= Wbur.org}}[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VU-QT8ewQYM "O.J.: Made in America" wins Best Documentary Feature-YouTube] ==Synopsis== Owen Suskind was a boy of considerable promise, until he's diagnosed with autism at the age of 3. As Owen withdrew into his silent state, his parents almost lost hope that he would find some way to meaningfully interact with his world. However, that way was found through animated films, especially ones by Walt Disney Pictures, which provided Owen a way to understand the world through its stories to the point of creating his own and grew obsessed with despite also owning some non-Disney movies, too. This film covers the life of Owen and how he manages to become as functional as possible with the help of Disney and his family to the point of having his own life. However, Owen soon learns as well that there is more to real life than what Disney can illustrate in animation even as his family prepares itself for an uncertain future with him. He gains and loses Emily who was his girlfriend because he got into her personal space according to her. ==Cast== * [[Jonathan Freeman (actor)|Jonathan Freeman]] – voice of Jafar * [[Gilbert Gottfried]] – voice of Iago * Alan Rosenblatt * Owen Suskind * [[Ron Suskind]] ==Production== The animation is done by [[Mac Guff]], which also worked on [[Illumination Entertainment]] films such as ''[[Despicable Me]]'' and ''[[The Lorax (film)|The Lorax]]''.{{cite web|url=http://fourthreefilm.com/2016/08/life-animated-an-interview-with-roger-ross-williams/|title=Life, Animated – An Interview with Roger Ross Williams|date=12 August 2016|publisher=}} To secure the rights for the clips and characters used in the film, Williams showed the unfinished product to the heads of department put together by Disney Productions president Sean Bailey. Roger refers to it as "the day I made the lawyers cry" after the end of the presentation. The films selected for the film were "100% Suskind".{{cite web|url=http://www.thewrap.com/life-animated-director-secured-rights-classic-disney-characters/|title='Life, Animated' Director on How They Secured the Rights to Use Classic Disney Characters|date=15 November 2016|publisher=}} ==Reception== The [[review aggregator]] website [[Rotten Tomatoes]] reported a 94% approval rating based on 96 reviews, with an average rating of 7.6/10. The website's critical consensus reads, "Life, Animated offers a heartwarming look at one family's journey, and a fascinating message that's more than enough to outweigh its unanswered questions."{{cite web|url=https://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/life_animated/|title=Life, Animated (2016)|work=Rotten Tomatoes|accessdate=January 17, 2017}} On [[Metacritic]], the film holds a score of 75 out of 100, based on 25 critics, indicating "generally favorable reviews".{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/movie/life-animated/|title=Life, Animated|work=Metacritic|accessdate=January 17, 2017}} ''[[The Guardian]]''{{'}}s critic Lanre Bakare praised the film and said, "It's a beguiling mix of animated storytelling and narration that doesn't flinch from exploring the emotional highs and lows that accompany a life with autism."{{cite web|title=Life, Animated review – how Disney films helped a boy with autism|url= https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/jan/29/life-animated-review-how-disney-films-helped-a-boy-with-autism|last=Bakare |first=Lanre|publisher=''The Guardian''|date=January 29, 2016|accessdate=January 17, 2017}} [[Kenneth Turan]] of ''[[LA Times]]'' lauded the film and said, "[Williams] spent two years on this project, and the trust everyone involved placed in him allowed for an emotional honesty that is ''Life, Animated''{{'}}s greatest strength."{{cite web|title='Life, Animated' follows an autistic boy's astonishing journey back to the world with the help of Disney movies|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/movies/la-et-mn-life-animated-review-20160627-snap-story.html|last=Turan|first=Kenneth |publisher=''LA Times''|date=June 30, 2016|accessdate=January 17, 2017}} Writing for ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'', Justin Chang wrote, "This latest film from [[Roger Ross Williams]] ("God Loves Uganda") teems with insights into how children's fantasy can and can't bridge a developmental gap, but works on an even more basic, emotional level as a warm testament to a family's love and resilience."{{cite web|title=Film Review: 'Life, Animated'|url=https://variety.com/2016/film/festivals/life-animated-review-1201699114/|last=Chang|first=Justin|publisher=''Variety''|date=February 6, 2016|accessdate=January 17, 2017}} ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]''{{'}}s Duane Byrge called it "a documentary gem."{{cite web|title='Life, Animated': Sundance Review|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/review/life-animated-sundance-review-859879|last=Byrge|first=Duane|publisher=''The Hollywood Reporter''|date=January 27, 2016|accessdate=January 17, 2017}} Ann Hornaday of ''[[The Washington Post]]'' positively reviewed the series and said, "''Life, Animated'' makes fascinating points, about the power of cinema, about meeting our loved ones where they are and, as Ron says, about who gets to decide what constitutes a meaningful life"{{cite web|title='Life, Animated': A young man's obsession with Disney helps him navigate autism |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/goingoutguide/movies/life-animated-a-young-mans-obsession-with-disney-helps-him-navigate-autism/2016/07/07/7852a6c4-3e0d-11e6-80bc-d06711fd2125_story.html |last=Hornaday|first=Ann|publisher=''The Washington Post''|date=July 7, 2016| accessdate=January 17, 2017}} ''[[Rolling Stone]]''{{'}}s chief film critic [[Peter Travers]] said, "In no way does Owen's story claim to be a cure-all. Instead of false hope, it offers up possibility, the chance of a stimulus that might get past the blocks of developmental disorder. That's more than encouraging. Life, Animated is truly inspirational."{{cite web|title=Life, Animated A young autistic man connects to the world through Disney movies in this inspiring doc|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/movies/reviews/life-animated-20160628|last=Travers|first=Peter|publisher= ''The Rolling Stone''|date=Jul 1, 2016| accessdate=January 17, 2017}} Writing for ''[[The A.V. Club]]'', [[Noel Murray]] said, "On the list of Disney-related 2016 releases about child-rearing and handicaps, this one goes just above "Finding Dory." What it lacks in wacky hijinks, it makes up in hard truths."{{cite web|title=A love of Disney helps an autistic adult understand the world in Life, Animated|url=http://www.avclub.com/review/love-disney-helps-autistic-adult-understand-world--238829| last=Murray |first =Noel |publisher=''The A.V. Club''|date=June 29, 2016|accessdate=January 17, 2017}} Reviewing for ''[[RogerEbert.com]]'' film critic Sheila O'Malley wrote, "Powerful and emotional, without being manipulative. It is deeply inspiring, without trying to be. It is honest about Owen's struggles, and the struggles of his family."{{cite web|title=Life, Animated, Review|url= http://www.rogerebert.com/reviews/life-animated-2016| last= O'Malley |first=Sheila|publisher=''RogerEbert.com''|date=Jul 1, 2016 |accessdate=January 17, 2017}} ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]''{{'}}s, Joe McGovern also lauded the series saying, "The Suskinds' humongous hearts are obviously in the right place and their openness is to be admired and encouraged - even if a book, more than a movie, remains the better venue to fairly and honestly tell Owen's extraordinary story."{{cite web|title=Life, Animated, EW Review |url=http://ew.com/article/2016/06/30/life-animated-ew-review/|last=McGovern|first=Joe |publisher=''Entertainment Weekly''|date=June 30, 2016 |accessdate=January 17, 2017}} Kyle Smith of ''[[New York Post]]'' explained, "''Life, Animated'' oversimplifies the situation, contriving to use endless clips from Disney movies to make a case that movie magic really can better people's lives. Unfortunately, by the end of the movie it's clear that Disney can't help Owen negotiate sex, breakups or many other challenges he faces as an adult."{{cite web|title=Disney helps an autistic boy navigate life in this new doc|url=https://nypost.com/2016/06/30/disney-helps-an-autistic-boy-navigate-life-in-this-new-doc/|last=Smith|first=Kyle|publisher=''New York Post''|date=June 30, 2016|accessdate=January 17, 2017}} Some publications however were more critical towards the film. In a lukewarm review of ''[[Empire (magazine)|Empire]]'' David Parkinson wrote, "A touch twee at times, but the use of classic and original animation is admirable, while Owen emerges as the king of sidekicks."{{cite web|title=Life, Animated Empie Review|url=http://www.empireonline.com/movies/life-animated/review/|last=Parkinson|first=David|publisher=''Empire'' |date=December 12, 2016|accessdate=January 17, 2017}} Film critic [[Anthony Lane]] of ''[[The New Yorker]]'' said, "Owen has made immense progress, to which Life, Animated is a stirring tribute, yet it leaves a trail of questions unanswered or unasked."{{cite web|title="Cafe Society" and "Life, Animated" Reviews|url=http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2016/07/11/cafe-society-and-life-animated-reviews|last=Lane|first=Anthony|publisher=''The New Yorker'' |date=July 4, 2016|accessdate=January 17, 2017}} ''[[The New York Times]]''{{'}}s Jeannette Catsoulis quipped, "Belaboring the cartoon connection, the director leaves the family struggles that enrich Mr. Suskind's 2014 book of the same title stubbornly veiled."{{cite web|title=Review: In 'Life, Animated,' a Bound Mind Finds Freedom|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/07/01/movies/review-life-animated.html|last=Catsoulis |first=Jeannette |publisher=''The New York Times'' |date=June 30, 2016|accessdate=January 17, 2017}} In a less enthusiastic review for ''[[Slant Magazine]]'' Clayton Dillard stated, "It never addresses Disney's wholly manufactured stranglehold on turning adolescent desire into a consumerist impulse."{{cite web|title=Film Review: Life, Animated |url=http://www.slantmagazine.com/film/review/life-animated|last=Clayton|first=Dillard|publisher=''Slant Magazine'' |date=June 27, 2016|accessdate=January 17, 2017}} ==Land of the Lost Sidekicks== An exclusive short, based on Owen's [[fan fic]] featuring younger version of himself and his favorite Disney sidekicks battling against the evil Fuzzbutch, was released on The Wrap in 2016.{{cite web|url=http://www.thewrap.com/watch-life-animated-short-land-of-the-lost-sidekicks-exclusive/|title=Watch 'Life, Animated's' Original Short, 'Land of the Lost Sidekicks' (Exclusive Video)|date=14 February 2017|publisher=}} Sidekicks used in the film: * Baloo from ''[[The Jungle Book (1967 film)|The Jungle Book]]'' * Timon and Rafiki from ''[[The Lion King]]'' * Iago and Abu from ''[[Aladdin (1992 Disney film)|Aladdin]]'' * Lucky Jack from ''[[Home on the Range (2004 film)|Home on the Range]]'' * Sebastian from ''[[The Little Mermaid (1989 film)|The Little Mermaid]]'' ==Accolades== {| [[Book store|Booksellers]] use standard terms to describe the condition of the used [[book]]s that they sell. The set of terms below were proposed in 1949 by [[AB Bookman's Weekly]]. They were adopted by the bookselling community and are still in use today.Chernofsky 1991 p. 183Hollowell 2010{{cite web|url=http://www.powells.com/rarebooks/bookbasics.html#condition |title=Rare books basics |publisher=Powell's City of Books |accessdate=October 11, 2014 |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141027043550/http://www.powells.com/rarebooks/bookbasics.html#condition |archivedate=October 27, 2014 }} *'''As New''' is self-explanatory. It means that the book is in the state that it should have been in when it left the publisher. This is the equivalent of [[Mint condition]] in [[numismatics]]. *'''Fine''' (F or FN) is As New but allowing for the normal effects of time on an unused book that has been protected. A fine book shows no damage. *'''Very Good''' (VG) describes a book that is worn but untorn. For many collectors this is the minimum acceptable condition for all but the rarest items. Any defects must be noted. *'''Good''' (G) describes the condition of an average used worn book that is complete. Any defects must be noted. *'''Fair''' shows wear and tear but all the text pages and illustrations or maps are present. It may lack endpapers, half-title, and even the title page. All defects must be noted. *'''Poor''' describes a book that has the complete text but is so damaged that it is only of interest to a buyer who seeks a reading copy. If the damage renders the text illegible then the book is not even ''poor''. *'''Ex-library''' copies must always be designated as such ''no matter what the condition of the book''. *'''Book Club''' copies must always be designated as such ''no matter what the condition of the book''. *'''Binding Copy''' describes a book in which the pages or leaves are perfect, but the binding is very bad, loose, off or non-existent. In all cases, the lack of a dust jacket should be noted if the book was issued with one. The same applies to other possible accessories, such as inlays (like [[errata]] lists, cards, photo prints, [[Printed circuit board|PCB]]s), foldouts (like maps), media (like [[diskette]]s, [[CD]]s, [[DVD]]s) etc. There is no standard term for books in a condition below poor. Their normal fate is to be discarded or to be broken into individual pages if these have any value. == After the Internet begins == With the advent of the internet AB Bookman's Weekly magazine declined and its place was taken by the internet listing services starting with [[Alibris|Interloc]] in 1994. These services, for their own purposes, have made modifications to this list. [[Amazon.com|Amazon]] adds the terms "acceptable", for example.{{cite web | url=https://www.amazon.com/gp/help/customer/display.html?nodeId=1161242#CSCG | title=Amazon book conditions | accessdate=October 4, 2014}} ==See also== *[[Foxing]] *[[List of booksellers' abbreviations]] ==References== ;Notes {{reflist|2}} ;Bibliography {{refbegin}} * Chernofsky, Jacob L., editor. ''Bookman's Yearbook 1990-1991''. Clifton, NJ: Bookman's Weekly, 1991. * {{Cite web | last = Hollowell | first = Hugh | title = The Original AB Bookman Grading Scale 1949 | url=http://www.hughlh.com/2007/the-original-ab-bookman-grading-scale-1949/ | access-date = 28 October 2010}} {{refend}} ==See also== * [http://www.abebooks.com/books/RareBooks/collecting-guide/understanding-rare-books/guide-book-conditions.shtml ABEBooks list of book conditions] * [http://mywingsbooks.com/home/grading.shtml IOBA grading system] {{Books}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Used book conditions, List of}} [[Category:Book collecting|*]] [[Category:Book terminology]]
