[[File:Hipp hipp hurra! Konstnärsfest på Skagen - Peder Severin Krøyer.jpg|thumb|350px|[[Peder Severin Krøyer|P.S. Krøyer]]: ''[[Hip, Hip, Hurrah!]]'' (1888) depicting the group's festivities]] [[File:Michael Ancher - A stroll on the beach - Google Art Project.jpg|thumb|350px|[[Michael Ancher]]: ''A Stroll on the Beach'' (1896)]] The '''Skagen Painters''' ({{lang-da|'''Skagensmalerne'''}}) were a group of Scandinavian artists who gathered in the village of [[Skagen]], the northernmost part of [[Denmark]], from the late 1870s until the turn of the century. Skagen was a summer destination whose scenery and quality of light attracted northern artists to paint ''[[en plein air]]'', emulating the French [[Impressionist]]s—though members of the Skagen colony were also influenced by [[realism (arts)|Realist]] movements such as the [[Barbizon school]]. They broke away from the rather rigid traditions of the [[Royal Danish Academy of Fine Arts]] and the [[Royal Swedish Academy of Arts]], espousing the latest trends that they had learned in [[Paris]]. Among the group were [[Anna Ancher|Anna]] and [[Michael Ancher]], [[Peder Severin Krøyer]], [[Holger Drachmann]], [[Karl Madsen]], [[Laurits Tuxen]], [[Marie Triepcke Krøyer Alfvén|Marie Krøyer]], [[Carl Locher]], [[Viggo Johansen]] and [[Thorvald Niss]] from Denmark, [[Oscar Björck]] and [[Johan Krouthén]] from Sweden, and [[Christian Krohg]] and [[Eilif Peterssen]] from Norway. The group gathered together regularly at the [[Brøndums Hotel|Brøndums Inn]].
Skagen, in the very north of [[Jutland]], was the largest fishing community in Denmark, with more than half of its population so engaged. Among the locals, fishermen were by far the most common subject for the Skagen painters. Skagen's long beaches were exploited in the group's landscapes; P.S. Krøyer, one of the best-known of the Skagen painters, was inspired by the light of the evening "[[Blue hour|Blue hour]]", which made the water and sky seem to optically merge. This is captured in one of his most famous paintings, ''[[Summer Evening at Skagen Beach – The Artist and his Wife]]'' (1899). Although the painters had their own individual styles without any requirement to adhere to a common approach or manifest, one of their common interests was to paint scenes of their own social gatherings, playing cards, celebrating or simply eating together.
Michael Ancher drew attention to the attractions of the area when his ''[[Will He Round the Point?]]'' (1885) was purchased by [[Christian IX of Denmark|King Christian IX]]. He married Anna Brøndum, the only member of the group from Skagen, who became a pioneering female artist at a time when women were not permitted to study at Denmark's Royal Academy. Today the [[Skagens Museum]], founded in the dining room at Brøndum's Hotel in October 1908, hosts many of their works of art, some 1,800 pieces in total. Many of the paintings have been digitized under the [[Google Art Project]] and are accessible online. Related exhibitions continue to be held; in 2008, the [[Arken Museum of Modern Art]] in Copenhagen presented "The Skagen Painters—In a New Light", and in 2013, the [[National Museum of Women in the Arts]] in Washington, D.C. presented "A World Apart: Anna Ancher and the Skagen Art Colony".
==History== [[File:Brøndums Hotel 1891-92.jpg|thumb|right|Dining room in Brøndums Hotel (ca. 1891) showing some of the group and the panel of their portraits]]
The first notable artist to paint in [[Skagen]] was [[Martinus Rørbye]] (1803–1848), one of the central figures of the [[Danish Golden Age|Golden Age of Danish Painting]]. His first visit was in 1833 but he returned towards the end of his life in 1847 and 1848. He is remembered in particular for his ''[[Men of Skagen on a Summer Evening in Fair Weather]]'' painted in 1848.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.kulturarv.dk/kid/VisWeilbach.do?kunstnerId=1049&wsektion=alle|title=Martinus Rørbye|publisher=''Kunstindekx Danmark & Weilbachs Kunstnerleksikon''|language=Danish|accessdate=1 November 2013}}</ref> Another marine painter, [[Vilhelm Melbye]] (1824–1882), visited Skagen in 1848, painting his [[:File:Vilhelm Melbye Udsigt over Skagen 1848-crop.jpg|''View over Skagen'']].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.denstoredanske.dk/Kunst_og_kultur/Billedkunst/Danmark_1850-1910/Vilhelm_Melbye|title=Vilhelm Melbye|publisher= ''Den Store Danske''|language=Danish|accessdate=1 November 2013}}</ref> According to Karl Madsen, the painter [[Johan Peter Raadsig|Peter Raadsig]] (1806–1882) also visited the town on several occasions between 1862 and 1870, painting the dunes and the fishermen.<ref name="Svanholm2003">{{cite book|last=Svanholm|first=Lise|title=Skagenleksikon: malerne, modellerne, værkerne og stederne|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gx11wFWqMSUC&pg=PA27|year=2003|publisher=Gyldendal A/S|isbn=978-87-02-01947-6|pages=27, 47, 57–}}</ref> [[Christian Blache]] (1838–1920), another marine painter, first visited Skagen in 1869 when he painted his [[:File:Blache Det grå fyr 1869.jpg|''Grey Lighthouse'']]. It was as a result of his influence that the poet and dramatist Holger Drachmann first visited the town in 1871.<ref name="Svanholm2003"/>
In the 1860s and 1870s, despite evolving trends in Europe, especially in Paris, embracing Realism and Impressionism, the Royal Danish Academy of Fine Arts and the Royal Swedish Academy of Arts refused to change their approach, insisting their students should continue to paint in the preferred styles of Historicism and Neoclassicism.{{Sfn|Svanholm|2004|p=32}} Among those who were increasingly frustrated by this approach were Michael Ancher, Karl Madsen and Viggo Johansen who in the early 1870s were studying at the Royal Danish Academy in Copenhagen. Madsen, who had already visited Skagen in 1871 while staying with his uncle in nearby [[Frederikshavn]], invited Ancher to join him there in 1874, to paint the local fishermen.{{Sfn|Svanholm|2004|p=54}} He became a friend of the Brøndum family who had a shop with a bar which was soon extended to become [[Brøndums Hotel|''Brøndums Gastgiveri'']], a [[guest house (lodging)|guest house]]. He was invited to their 15-year-old daughter Anna's [[confirmation]] and showed an immediate interest in her. The following year, he returned to Skagen with both Madsen and Viggo Johansen who had been strongly influenced by French Impressionism. In particular, Johansen began to paint open-air scenes combining Impressionism with Realism.<ref name="Sandby"/>
[[File:The Apostle (Carl Locher).jpg|thumb|left|[[Carl Locher]], ''Mail Coach on Skagen Beach'' (c. 1890)]] In 1876 and especially in 1877, several other artists spent the summer in Skagen, using the Brøndums' house for accommodation and their frequent gatherings. Michael Ancher made Skagen his new home. He became engaged to Anna Brøndum in 1878 and married her in 1880. Their home then became a focal point for the artists, especially after King Christian IX bought Ancher's painting ''Will He Round the Point?''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.skagensmuseum.dk/samlingen/vaerkerne/michael-ancher/pynten/ |title=Michael Ancher: Vil han klare pynten? – Ca. 1880|publisher= Skagens Museum|language=Danish|accessdate=15 October 2013}}</ref> Anna Ancher first took a serious interest in painting after the artists began to stay in her family's inn, leaving their paintings to dry in their rooms when they left for the day. She studied them carefully and in 1875 attended [[Vilhelm Kyhn]]'s art school in Copenhagen. She was later influenced by Christian Krohg who taught her the art of painting people in their everyday lives and making full use of colour.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kvinfo.dk/side/597/bio/293/origin/170/ |title=Elisabeth Fabritius, "Anna Ancher"|publisher= ''Dansk Kvindebiografisk Leksikon''|language=Danish|accessdate=18 August 2014}}</ref> Krohg first came to Skagen in the summer of 1878, encouraged by Georg Brandes whom he had met in Berlin. He brought many of the latest international art trends with him, influencing the other members of the group. His encounters with the local population also exerted a strong influence on his own work.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.skagensmuseum.dk/index.php?id=120 |title=Christian Krohg og Skagen|publisher=Skagens Museum|language=Danish|accessdate=18 August 2014}}</ref>
[[File:Ved Frokosten Krøyer 1883.jpg|thumb|P.S. Krøyer: ''Artists at Lunch'' (1883)]] In 1882, the Anchers travelled abroad. While they were in [[Vienna]], they met P.S. Krøyer who informed them he would also be going to Skagen that year, despite the fact that Ancher was apparently not too keen to have him there. Krøyer, who had enjoyed close contacts with several Impressionist artists in [[Paris]], immediately became the central member and unofficial leader of the artists' colony. In 1883, he created the "Evening Academy" where the artists gathered to paint and discuss each other's work, often enjoying champagne.<ref>Alba Schwartz, "Skagen – Den nye Tid i Oplevelser og Indtryk", Skagens Museum, 1992, pp 117–120. {{ISBN|978-87-983631-1-8}}</ref> In 1884, the German painter [[Fritz Stoltenberg]] took photographs of the artists celebrating in the Anchers' garden, just after the couple had moved into their new home. One of these photos in particular inspired Krøyer to paint ''[[Hip, Hip, Hurrah!]]'', which took him four years to complete.<ref name="Sandby"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.skagensmuseum.dk/en/collection/hip-hip-hurray/|title=Hip, Hip, Hurray!|publisher=Skagens Museum|accessdate=15 October 2013}}</ref>
In 1890, the railway's arrival in Skagen not only led to the expansion of the village but also brought in considerable numbers of tourists. It was largely responsible for breaking up the regular summer meetings of the artists as they could no longer find suitable accommodation or venues for their meetings. However, some of them purchased homes in Skagen: P.S. Krøyer in 1894, Laurits Tuxen in 1901 and Holger Drachmann in 1903.<ref>Mona Jensen (editor), "Danske kunstnerkolonier. Skagen. Fyn. Bornholm", Aarhus Kunstmuseums Forlag, 2000.</ref>
Anna and Michael Ancher, Krøyer and Tuxen continued to paint in Skagen until well into the 20th century and were occasionally joined by their earlier friends. Two core members of the group, Drachmann and Krøyer, died in 1908 and 1909, bringing the traditional gatherings of the group to an end. There were nevertheless other painters, sometimes referred to as the younger group of Skagen painters, who continued to visit the area. They included [[Jørgen Aabye]], [[Tupsy Clement|Tupsy]] and [[Gad Frederik Clement]], [[Ella Heide]], [[Ludvig Karsten]], [[Frederik Lange]] and [[Johannes Wilhjelm]], some of whom settled in the area until the 1930s or even later. [[Skagens Museum]] has a number of their works in its collection.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kulturarv.dk/fileadmin/user_upload/kulturarv/museer/dokumenter/arbejdsplaner/Skagens_Museum.pdf|title=Skagens Museum: Insamling|publisher=Kulturarv.dk|language=Danish|accessdate=29 October 2013}}</ref> Another notable artist who visited Skagen from 1906 was [[J.F. Willumsen]] who painted ''Children Bathing on Skagen Beach'' in 1909.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.skagensmuseum.dk/udstillinger/tidligere-udstillinger/salon/willumsens-billede/|title=J.F. Willumsen: Badende børn på Skagen strand. 1909|publisher=Skagens Museum|language=Danish|accessdate=11 November 2013}}</ref>
==Family relationships== [[File:Marie krøyer p.s. krøyer.jpg|thumb|right|Marie Krøyer painted by her husband, P.S. Krøyer (1890)]] The Skagen painters quickly began to form a close-knit community as relationships grew between the artists and the young women from the area. In 1880, Michael Ancher married Anna Brøndum from the guest house, Viggo Johansen married Martha Møller, Anna's cousin, and Karl Madsen married Helene Christensen, a schoolteacher. The [[Michael and Anna Ancher House|house]] the Anchers moved into in 1884 became a focus for the artists' colony, especially as the couple lived there all the year round. When their daughter [[Helga Ancher|Helga]] (the little girl in ''Hip, Hip, Hurrah!'') died in 1964, she left the house to a foundation which soon turned it into a museum.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.anchershus.dk/|title=Michael og Anna Anchers Hus / Saxilds Gaard|publisher= Anchershus.dk|language=Danish|accessdate=15 October 2013}}</ref> The Johansens acquired a large family between 1881 and 1886: Ellen Henriette (daughter of Henriette, Martha's sister, who died during childbirth), Lars, Fritz, Gerda and Bodil. They can be seen dancing around the Christmas tree in Johansen's painting [[:File:Johansen Viggo - Radosne Boże Narodzenie.jpg|''Merry Christmas'']].{{sfn|Svanholm|2006|p=62}}
Another key figure in Skagen, P.S. Krøyer, married Marie Triepcke after falling in love with her in Paris in 1888.{{Sfn|Svanholm|2004|p=259}} The daughter of a prosperous German loomery engineer, she was said to be the most beautiful woman in Copenhagen. However, as the years went by, Krøyer's health began to deteriorate and Marie was increasingly unhappy with their marriage. The marriage finally ended in a divorce in 1905 when Marie became pregnant after an affair with the composer [[Hugo Alfvén]] whom she then married. Krøyer died in Skagen four years later, apparently as a result of mental illness.{{Sfn|Svanholm|2004|pp= 30–43}}
In 1901, after the death of his first wife Ursule, Laurits Tuxen married Frederikke Treschow, a Norwegian, and shortly afterwards purchased Madam Bendsen's house in Skagen where first Viggo and Martha Johansen and later Marie and P.S. Krøyer had stayed in the 1880s. He converted it into a stately summer residence.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.skagensiden.dk/asp/page.asp?id=2 |title=Madam Bendsens gård|publisher=Skagen i gamle dage|language=Danish|accessdate=18 August 2014}}</ref> Michael Ancher and Laurits Tuxen died in 1927,{{sfn|Norman|1977|p=31}}{{sfn|Svanholm|2004|p=274}} Anna Ancher and Viggo Johansen in 1935.{{Sfn|Gaze|2013|p=154}}{{sfn|Kent|2001|p=96}}
==Members of the group== [[File:P.S. Krøyer - Roses. Marie Krøyer seated in the deckchair in the garden by Mrs Bendsen's house - Google Art Project.jpg|thumb|right|250px|P.S. Krøyer, ''[[Roses (painting)|Roses]]'' (1893)]] The principal Danish painters included Karl Madsen, Laurits Tuxen, Marie Krøyer, Carl Locher, Viggo Johansen, Thorvald Niss, and most notably, Anna and Michael Ancher and Peder Severin Krøyer. There were also painters from the rest of Scandinavia including Oscar Björck and Johan Krouthén from Sweden and Christian Krohg and Eilif Peterssen from Norway. The gatherings in Skagen were not restricted to painters. The Danish writers [[Georg Brandes]], Holger Drachmann and [[Henrik Pontoppidan]] and the Swedish composer Hugo Alfvén were also members of the group.<ref name="Sandby">Vibeke Sandby, Pernille and Jens Agerholm, "Skagens trofaste veninde", Agenholm, 2000. {{Da icon}} {{ISBN|87-987939-1-8}}</ref>
A number of other artists also joined the Skagen Painters for shorter periods. From Denmark they included Vilhelm Kyhn, [[Einar Hein]] and Frederik Lange, from Norway [[Frits Thaulow]], [[Charles Lundh]] and [[Wilhelm Peters (painter)|Wilhelm Peters]], from Sweden [[Wilhelm von Gegerfelt]] and [[Anna Palm de Rosa]], from Germany Fritz Stoltenberg and [[Julius Runge]], and from England [[Adrian Scott Stokes|Adrian Stokes]] and his Austrian-born wife, [[Marianne Stokes]]. The Danish composer [[Carl Nielsen]] and his wife [[Anne Marie Carl-Nielsen|Anne Marie]], a sculptor, also spent summers in Skagen and eventually bought a summerhouse there.{{Sfn|Svanholm|2004|pp= 30–43}}<ref>[http://carlnielsen.dk/pages/biography/family-life.php "Family life", ''Carl Nielsen Society'']. Retrieved 29 August 2010.</ref>
===Anna Ancher=== [[File:Michael Ancher, Anna Ancher.jpg|thumb|120px| [[Michael Ancher|Ancher]]'s ''Anna Ancher'' (1902)]] The only member of the group born in Skagen, Anna Ancher (1859–1935), was the daughter of Erik Brøndum, the owner of the grocery shop and guest house which later became Brøndums Hotel. Inspired by the artists who stayed there, she received her first lessons from Karl Madsen, Viggo Johansen and Michael Ancher. From 1875, she spent several winters in Copenhagen at Vilhelm Kyhn's school for women painters.<ref name=smaa>{{cite web|url=http://www.skagensmuseum.dk/en/collection/the-artists/anna-ancher/|title=Anna Ancher (1859–1935) |publisher=Skagens Museum|accessdate=8 August 2014 |language=}}</ref> As a result of her portraits of family and friends as well as her skills as a colourist, she is considered to be one of Denmark's finest artists although her talents were not fully appreciated until after her death.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.denstoredanske.dk/Kunst_og_kultur/Billedkunst/Danmark_1850-1910/Anna_Kirstine_Ancher?highlight=anna%20ancher|title=Anna Ancher|publisher=''Den Store Danske''|accessdate=9 August 2014 |language=Danish}}</ref> Her works depict scenes from the home, children and women and religious life in Skagen. She now stands out as a pioneer at a time when women were not expected to become artists and were not admitted to the Royal Danish Academy.<ref name=smaa/> Unlike her husband, she adopted a style of Realism, inspired above all by Christian Krohg. Commenting on her ''[[:File:Anna Ancher - A blind woman in her room - Google Art Project.jpg|Blind Woman]]'' (1882) in which the face is illuminated in an otherwise dark portrait, Madsen pointed out that she was the first Danish artist to depict a sunbeam.{{Sfn|Svanholm|2004|p=69}} Her most cherished works include [[:File:Anna Ancher Pigen i koekkenet 1883-86.jpg|''Girl in the Kitchen'']] (1886), ''[[Sunlight in the Blue Room]]'' (1891) and [[:File:Mission Meeting at Fyrbakken in Skagen.jpg|''A Mission Meeting'']] (1903).
===Michael Ancher=== [[File:P.S. Krøyer - Michael Ancher - Google Art Project.jpg|thumb|120px|left|P.S. Krøyer: ''Michael Ancher'' (1886)]] Michael Ancher (1849–1927), originally from the island of [[Bornholm]], was invited to Skagen in 1874 by his friend Karl Madsen with whom he was studying at the Academy. In 1880, he married Anna Brøndum and settled in Skagen. He achieved his artistic breakthrough in 1879 with the painting ''Will he Round the Point?'' which was bought by Christian IX. Several other works by Ancher depict Skagen's heroic fishermen and their dramatic experiences at sea, combining Realism and with classical composition.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.kulturarv.dk/kid/VisWeilbach.do?kunstnerId=133&wsektion=alle|title=Michael Ancher|publisher=''Kunstindeks Danmark & Weilbachs Kunstnerleksikon''|accessdate=4 August 2014 |language=Danish}}</ref><ref name=sm>{{cite web|url=http://www.skagensmuseum.dk/en/collection/the-artists/michael-ancher/|title=Michael Ancher (1849–1927)|publisher=Skagens Museum|accessdate=4 August 2014 |language=}}</ref> Key works include ''[[:File:Redningsbåden køres gennem klitterne.jpg|The Lifeboat is Carried Through The Dunes]]'' (1883), [[:File:Mandskabet reddet (Michael Ancher).jpg|''The Crew Are Saved'']] (1894) and [[:File:Ancher02 den druknede.jpg|''The Drowned Man'']] (1896). He also painted portraits and landscapes, especially of Skagen's Østerby district. Many of his paintings can be seen in Skagens Museum. Michael Ancher has become one of Denmark's most cherished painters.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.denstoredanske.dk/Kunst_og_kultur/Billedkunst/Danmark_1850-1910/Michael_Peter_Ancher|title=Michael Peter Ancher|publisher=''Den Store Danske''|accessdate=6 August 2014 |language=Danish}}</ref>
===P.S. Krøyer=== [[File:P S Krøyer 1897 - Selvportræt.jpg|thumb|120px|P.S. Krøyer: Self-portrait (1899)]]
Born in [[Stavanger]], Norway, but brought up in Copenhagen, Peder Severin Krøyer (1851–1909) came to Skagen in 1882 and returned almost every summer, finally settling there after marrying Marie Triepcke in 1889.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.skagensmuseum.dk/en/collection/the-artists/ps-kroeyer/|title=P.S. Krøyer (1851–1909)|publisher=Skagens Museum|accessdate=6 August 2014}}</ref> He had already gained a reputation for his paintings of the fishermen in [[Hornbæk]] on the north coast of [[Zealand]] and had been influenced by the Impressionist movement in his travels to France. In Skagen, he became one of the central and most enthusiastic members of the group of painters, creating masterpieces emphasizing the special effects of the local light in his beach scenes while painting several memorable works recording the lively gatherings of the artists.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.denstoredanske.dk/Kunst_og_kultur/Billedkunst/Danmark_1850-1910/Peder_Severin_Kr%C3%B8yer?highlight=p.s.%20kr%C3%B8yer|title=P.S. Krøyer|publisher=''Den Store Danske''|accessdate=6 August 2014 |language=Danish}}</ref> Key works include [[:File:Krøyer Sommeraften Skagen Sønderstrand.jpg|''Summer Evening on Skagen's Southern Beach'']] (1893), [[:File:I købmandens bod (Peder Severin Krøyer).jpg|''In the Grocer's Store When There is No Fishing'']] (1892), and ''[[Midsummer Eve Bonfire on Skagen Beach]]'' (1906) which shows many members of the community including Krøyer's daughter Vibeke, mayor Otto Schwartz and his wife Alba Schwartz, Michael Ancher, Degn Brøndum, Anna Ancher, Holger Drachmann and his third wife Soffi, Hugo Alfvén and Marie Krøyer.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.denstoredanske.dk/Kunst_og_kultur/Billedkunst/Danmark_1850-1910/Peder_Severin_Kr%C3%B8yer|title=P.S. Krøyer|publisher=''Den Store Danske''|accessdate=8 August 2014 |language=Danish}}</ref>
===Viggo Johansen=== [[File:Johansen viggo-self portrait with palette in hand and wife martha.jpg|thumb|left|120px|Viggo Johansen: ''Self-portrait with wife Martha'' (c. 1895)]] Viggo Johansen (1851–1935), who had studied at the Royal Academy with Michael Ancher (also without graduating), first went to Skagen in 1875. An active member of the group, he married Anna Ancher's cousin Martha Møller in 1880. From 1885, he exhibited in Paris where he was inspired by [[Claude Monet]]. His paintings took on lighter tones as he had noted the absence of black in the works of the French artists and considered his own earlier works too dark by comparison.{{Sfn|Svanholm|2004|p=99}} Monet's use of colour is reflected in his painting [[:File:Christian bindslev er syg.jpg|''Christian Bindslev is ill'']] (1890).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.denstoredanske.dk/Kunst_og_kultur/Billedkunst/Danmark_1850-1910/Viggo_Johansen|title=Viggo Johansen|publisher=''Den Store Danske''|accessdate=8 August 2014 |language=Danish}}</ref> The work displays stronger contrasts than his earlier paintings, depicting the red-bearded Christian looking out towards the light at the foot of his bed where the flaming gold and white sunlight streams down onto the little blue cupboard on the wall.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.denstoredanske.dk/Dansk_Biografisk_Leksikon/Kunst_og_kultur/Billedkunst/Maler/Viggo_Johansen|title=Viggo Johansen|publisher=''Dansk Biografisk Leksikon|accessdate=9 August 2014 |language=Danish}}</ref> Among the works he painted in Skagen are [[:File:Viggo Johansen - Kitchen interior. The artist's wife arranging flowers - Google Art Project.jpg|''Kitchen Interior'']] (1884) which depicts his wife Martha arranging flowers, and the much brighter [[:File:Dividing the catch (Viggo Johansen).jpg|''Dividing the Catch'']] (1885) showing four fishermen who have pulled their boat up onto the beach while one of their wives hopes there will be something for the evening meal.<ref name=dblvj>{{cite web|url=http://www.denstoredanske.dk/Dansk_Biografisk_Leksikon/Kunst_og_kultur/Billedkunst/Maler/Viggo_Johansen|title=Viggo Johansen|publisher=''Dansk Biografisk Leksikon''|accessdate=8 August 2014 |language=Danish}}</ref>{{Sfn|Svanholm|2004|p=98}} After falling out with P.S. Krøyer in 1891, Johansen's relationship with the Anchers was strained and he and his family did not visit Skagen for several years but finally returned in 1903.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.skagensmuseum.dk/en/collection/the-artists/viggo-johansen/|title=Viggo Johansen (1851–1935)|publisher=Skagens Museum|accessdate=8 August 2014 |language=}}</ref> In 1906, he became a professor at the Royal Academy where he was director from 1911 to 1914.<ref name=dblvj/>
===Carl Locher=== [[File:P.S. Krøyer - Carl Locher - Google Art Project.jpg|thumb|120px|P.S. Krøyer: ''Carl Locher'' (1885)]] Somewhat forgotten today, Carl Locher (1851–1915) was one of the earlier visitors to Skagen. Holgen Drachmann, who had taught him before he attended the Royal Academy, persuaded him to go there in 1872.<ref name=smcl>{{cite web|url=http://www.skagensmuseum.dk/en/collection/the-artists/carl-locher/|title=Carl Locher (1851–1915)|publisher=Skagens Museum|accessdate=9 August 2014 |language=}}</ref> Especially interested in [[marine painting]], Locher adopted a realist impressionistic approach, influenced by the time he spent with [[Léon Bonnat]] in Paris during the 1870s.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.denstoredanske.dk/Kunst_og_kultur/Billedkunst/Danmark_1850-1910/Carl_Locher|title=Carl Locher|publisher=''Den Store Danske''|accessdate=9 August 2014 |language=Danish}}</ref> A stickler for perfection, especially in his drawings, his works cover the transition from sailing ships to steamships and from the original Skagen to the evolving tourist destination.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://politiken.dk/kultur/boger/faglitteratur_boger/ECE1239717/skagensmaler-var-for-perfekt-til-at-blive-kendt/|title=Skagensmaler var for perfekt til at blive kendt|author=Henrik Holm|publisher=''Politiken''|date=31 March 2011|accessdate=9 August 2014 |language=Danish}}</ref> His paintings include [[:File:Carl Locher - Fishing cutters in the moonlit night - Google Art Project.jpg|''Fishing Cutters in the Moonlit Night'']], 1888, [[:File:Carl Locher - The lightship at Skagen Reef - Google Art Project.jpg|''The Lightship at Skagen Reef'']] (1892) and above all [[:File:The Apostle (Carl Locher).jpg|''The Mail Coach'']] (c. 1890) which depicts the horse-drawn carriage which until the railway reached Skagen in 1890 was the way travellers arrived there from Frederikshavn.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.skagensmuseum.dk/en/collection/the-art-works/carl-locher/the-mail-coach/#c2271|title=Carl Locher: The mail coach - 1885|publisher=Skagens Museum|accessdate=9 August 2014 |language=}}</ref> In 1910, Locher built a house overlooking the beach at Skagen Østerby where he painted until he died of heart trouble in 1913.<ref name=smcl/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.denstoredanske.dk/Dansk_Biografisk_Leksikon/Kunst_og_kultur/Billedkunst/Maler/Carl_Locher|title=Carl Locher|publisher=''Dansk Biografisk Leksikon''|accessdate=9 August 2014 |language=Danish}}</ref>
===Laurits Tuxen=== [[File:Laurits Tuxen - Self-portrait - Google Art Project.jpg|thumb|120px|left|Laurits Tuxen: self-portrait (1911)]]
Born and raised in Copenhagen, Laurits Tuxen (1853–1927) studied at the Royal Danish Academy together with P.S. Krøyer where he was considered to be one of the best painters. In 1875, he began to study in Paris in Léon Bonnat's studio with whom he also worked in subsequent years. His ''Suzanna i Badet'' (1878), first painted in Paris, was warmly received in the Copenhagen spring exhibition in 1879.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.denstoredanske.dk/Dansk_Biografisk_Leksikon/Kunst_og_kultur/Billedkunst/Maler/L._Tuxen|title=Laurits Tuxen|publisher=''Dansk Biografisk Leksikon''|accessdate=9 August 2014 |language=Danish}}</ref> He first visited Skagen in 1870 but after a few more visits in the 1870s, did not return until 1901. After his first wife died of tuberculosis, he married the Norwegian Frederikke Treschow and bought a house in Skagen. There he painted a number of pictures depicting family and friends as well as landscapes.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.skagensmuseum.dk/en/collection/the-artists/laurits-tuxen/|title=Laurits Tuxen (1853–1927)|publisher=Skagens Museum|accessdate= 9 August 2014|language=}}</ref> Among the works from Skagen are [[:File:Laurits Tuxen - The North Sea in stormy weather. After sunset. Højen - Google Art Project.jpg|''The North Sea in Stormy Weather'']] (1909), the powerful [[:File:Den druknede bringes i land (Laurits Tuxen).jpg|''The Drowned Boy is Brought Ashore'']] (1913) inspired by paintings of drownings he saw in France<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.skagensmuseum.dk/en/collection/the-art-works/laurits-tuxen/den-druknede-bringes-i-land/|title=Laurits Tuxen: The drowned boy is brought ashore - 1913|publisher=Skagens Museum|accessdate=9 August 2014 |language=}}</ref> and [[:File:Tuxen Morgenkaffe skenkes 1906-crop.jpg|''Pouring the Morning Coffee'']] (1906) depicting Tuxen's wife Frederikke and his daughters Yvonne and Nina in their Skagen home, Villa Dagminne. Through his use of colour, brushstrokes and backlighting through the window flowers, the artist creates a homely atmosphere.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.skagensmuseum.dk/en/collection/the-art-works/laurits-tuxen/morgenkaffen-skaenkes/|title=Laurits Tuxen: Pouring the morning coffee - (1906)|publisher=Skagens Museum|accessdate=9 August 2014 |language=}}</ref> Tuxen's most famous paintings are however his portraits of European royal personalities, including Christian IX of Denmark, [[Queen Victoria]] and [[Czar Nicholas II]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hermitagemuseum.org/html_En/04/2006/hm4_1_143.html|title=Lauritz Tuxen. Court Painter. Works from Danish and Russian collections|publisher=Hermitage Museum|accessdate=9 August 2014 |language=}}</ref>
===Christian Krohg=== [[File:P.S. Krøyer - Christian Krohg - Google Art Project.jpg|thumb|120px|P.S. Krøyer: ''Christian Krohg'' (1888)]]
The Norwegian Christian Krohg (1852–1925) first visited Skagen with Frits Thaulow in 1879.<ref name=dsdck>{{cite web|url=http://www.denstoredanske.dk/Kunst_og_kultur/Billedkunst/Kunstnere%2c_udland/Kunstnere%2c_nordiske_uden_danske/Christian_Krohg|title=Christian Krohg|publisher=''Den Store Danske''|accessdate=10 August 2014 |language=Danish}}</ref> One of the most important figures in Norwegian art, he first studied law but his interest in art was triggered by his friendship with fellow student Eilif Peterssen. He attended [[Johan Fredrik Eckersberg|J.F. Eckersberg]]'s painting school in Christiania (now Oslo) before moving to [[Karlsruhe]] and Berlin where he studied under [[Karl Gussow]], specializing in figure painting in the new idiom of Realism. In Berlin, he also developed a friendship with Georg Brandes. In 1879 he returned to Christiania before travelling to Skagen where he achieved his artistic breakthrough, attracted by the simple lives of the local fishermen. Depicting a fisherman at sea, his [[:File:Christian Krohg - Babord litt.jpg|''Babord litt'']] (1879) is considered to be one of his early masterpieces.<ref name=nblck/> His association with Ancher, Krøyer and the other members of the colony had a marked effect on his style as can be seen in the works he painted on returning to Norway.<ref name=nblck>{{cite web|url=http://nbl.snl.no/Christian_Krohg_-_2|title=Christian Krohg - 2|publisher=Norsk Biografisk Leksikon|accessdate=10 August 2014 |language=Norwegian}}</ref> He went to Paris in 1881–82, where was influenced by [[Édouard Manet]] and the Impressionist movement.<ref name=dsdck/> His experience of French art can be seen in several of his later Skagen paintings, including [[:File:C Krohg-Trett.jpg|''Tired'']] (1885) and [[:File:Christian Krohg - Braiding her Hair - Google Art Project.jpg|''Braiding Her Hair'']] (1888) in which the mother and child unusually have their backs facing the observer.{{Sfn|Svanholm|2004|p=81}} His lighter palette with bold brushstrokes and contrasting tones of blue, red and green give the painting a deeper texture.<ref name=nblck/>
===Marie Krøyer=== [[File:MarieKroyer-selfportrait.jpg|thumb|left|120px|Marie Krøyer: Self-portrait (c. 1900)]] Marie Krøyer née Triepcke (1867–1940) came from a well-to-do German family living in Copenhagen. From an early age she aspired to become an artist and after training privately she went to Paris to continue her studies. It was there, in early 1889, that she met Krøyer who immediately fell madly in love with her. Although he was 16 years her senior, the couple married that summer. In 1891, they settled in Skagen, giving Krøyer ample opportunity to paint portraits of Marie, both indoors and especially on the beach. The summers Krøyer spent together with his wife in the 1890s were clearly a source of inspiration for him, especially as Marie had a strong sense of beauty herself, often quoting [[Keats]]' "[[Ode on a Grecian Urn|Beauty is truth, truth beauty]]".{{Sfn|Svanholm|2004|p=132}} As a result of the periods of mental illness Krøyer experienced from 1900, the marriage fell apart. In 1912, she married Hugo Alfvén who had also been taken by her beauty. It is believed Marie was reluctant to paint after meeting Krøyer whom she looked up to as a far more competent artist. A few of her works have nevertheless survived, including ''[[:File:Interioer med syende pige.jpg|Interior with Girl Sewing]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kvinfo.dk/side/170/bio/546/|title=Marie Krøyer (1867–1940)|author=Lise Svanholm|publisher=''Dansk kvindebiografisk leksikon''|accessdate=9 September 2014 |language=Danish}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.kulturarv.dk/kid/VisWeilbach.do?kunstnerId=3784&wsektion=alle|title=Marie Krøyer|publisher=Kunstindeks Danmark & Weilbachs Kunstnerleksikon|accessdate=9 September 2014 |language=Danish}}</ref> {{clear all}}
==Styles of painting==
[[File:P S Krøyer 1899 - Sommeraften ved Skagens strand. Kunstneren og hans hustru.jpg|thumb|350px|P.S. Krøyer: ''[[Summer Evening at Skagen Beach – The Artist and his Wife]]'' (1899)]] Encouraged by the [[Modern Breakthrough]] movement led by Georg Brandes, the early painters were attracted by Skagen's village community, its seascapes and culture, all far removed from the effects of industrialization on city life. They all recognized the special light they encountered in Skagen, a combination of its location in the far north of Denmark and, by some accounts, the effects of sand in the air.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.altomhistorie.dk/artikler/skagensmalerne/|title=Skagensmalerne|publisher=Alt om Historie|accessdate=12 August 2014 |language=Danish}}</ref> Their painting styles evolved from the formal [[Neoclassicism|Neoclassical]] approach of the [[Royal Danish Academy of Fine Arts|Royal Academy]] in Copenhagen to embrace the evolving European trends in Realism and Impressionism, including the ''plein air'' approach adopted by the Barbizon School.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nmwa.org/sites/default/files/shared/anna_ancher_press_release_final.pdf|title=A World Apart: Anna Ancher and the Skagen Art Colony|publisher=National Museum of Women in the Arts|date=12 December 201|accessdate=12 August 2014 |language=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.metmuseum.org/toah/hd/bfpn/hd_bfpn.htm|title=The Barbizon School: French Painters of Nature|publisher=Heilbrunn Timeline of Art History|accessdate=21 August 2014 |language=}}</ref> The artists were especially attracted by the opportunities for painting ''[[en plein air]]'', focusing on the activities of the local fishermen and their modest cottages. In the absence of any rules within the colony, the painters freely developed their individual styles. Nevertheless, one of the interests they shared was to paint scenes of their own social gatherings, whether playing cards, celebrating or simply eating together.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.skagensmuseum.dk/en/collection/|title=Collection|publisher=Skagens Museum|accessdate=12 August 2014 |language=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.arken.dk/media%281548,1030%29|title=Skagensmalerne|publisher=Arken|accessdate=13 August 2014 |language=Danish}}</ref>
By adopting the plein-air approach, the painters were able to create their works in the open, immediately capturing the special effects of light and colour on their subjects.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.skagensmuseum.dk/en/collection/plein-air-painting/#c2004|title=Plein air painting|publisher=Skagens Museum|accessdate=12 August 2014 |language=}}</ref> Fishermen were considered an especially interesting group in view of their dangerous work and their heroic behaviour. [[Lars Kruse]], depicted by Michael Ancher, was famous for his success in rescuing a number of sailors who would otherwise have drowned. P.S. Krøyer's works were less dramatic, depicting fishermen pulling their nets in after a day at sea. While some of the paintings portrayed authentic occurrences, the artists often paid the fishermen to act as models, supplementing their modest incomes.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.skagensmuseum.dk/en/collection/the-fishermen-scene/#c2008|title=The fishermen scene|publisher=Skagens Museum|accessdate=12 August 2014 |language=}}</ref> Krøyer's works also included scenes of walks on the beach, romantic evenings in the moonlight and portraits of his wife Marie.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.skagensmuseum.dk/skoleservice/undervisningsmateriale/storvaerk-paa-skagen/ps-kroeyer/|title=P.S. Krøyer|publisher=Skagens Museum|accessdate=13 August 2014 |language=Danish}}</ref> As time went by, Krøyer increasingly painted "moods", works which depicted the special atmosphere of the "Blue Hour" which developed in the evening as the sky merged with the sea.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.skagensmuseum.dk/en/exhibitions/former-exhibitions/the-blue-hour/|title=Den Blaa Time|publisher=Skagens Museum|accessdate=20 August 2014 |language=}}</ref> In addition to his landscapes and family portraits, Laurits Tuxen is remembered for painting the flowers in his garden.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.skagensmuseum.dk/samlingen/kunstnerne/laurits-tuxen/|title=Laurits Tuxen (1853–1927)|publisher=Skagens Museum|accessdate=13 August 2014 |language=Danish}}</ref> Anna Ancher's paintings, on the other hand, focused on interiors of the home, including women and children, in a more abstract style.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.skagensmuseum.dk/skoleservice/undervisningsmateriale/storvaerk-paa-skagen/ps-kroeyer/|title=Anna Ancher|publisher=Skagens Museum|accessdate=13 August 2014 |language=Danish}}</ref><ref name=ab>{{cite web|url=http://www.ann-berit.dk/5.klasse/praktiske%20gris/Skagensmalerne.pdf|title=Skagensmalerne|publisher=ann-berit.dk |accessdate=13 August 2014 |language=Danish}}</ref>
==Skagens Museum== {{Main|Skagens Museum}} [[File:Skagens museum.jpg|thumb|left|Skagens Museum located in the old garden of Brøndums Hotel]] Skagens Museum was founded in the dining room at Brøndums Hotel in October 1908.{{Sfn|Svanholm|2006|p=230}} Victor Christian Klæbel, the local pharmacist, [[Degn Brøndum]], proprietor of Brøndums Hotel and Anna Ancher's brother, and Michael Ancher, Krøyer and Tuxen were elected to form the first board of governors. After P.S. Krøyer's death in 1909, his house in Skagen Plantation was used as a museum. In 1919, Degn Brøndum donated the old hotel's garden to Skagens Museum as a site for a new building. Work started in 1926 and was completed in September 1928 when the new museum was officially opened.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.skagensmuseum.dk/index.php?id=75|title=Museets historie|language=Danish|publisher=Skagens Museum|accessdate=25 October 2013}}</ref>
In 1982, the exhibition rooms were extended with an annex designed by the Royal Surveyor, architect Jacob Blegvad, who also planned the later extension to the museum inaugurated in 1989. In 1997, the museum administration moved into the Technical School. Today Skagens Museum has more than 1,800 works of art.<ref>[http://www.skagensmuseum.dk/index.php?id=7&L=2 "Skagens Museum"], Retrieved 19 August 2010.</ref> Many of the museum's paintings have been digitized under the [[Google Art Project]] and are accessible online.<ref>[https://www.google.com/culturalinstitute/collection/skagens-museum?projectId=art-project&hl=en "Skagens Museum"], Google Art Project. Retrieved 7 August 2013.</ref>
==Films== The Skagen artists were the subject of the 1987 film ''[[Hip hip hurra! (film)|Hip Hip Hurra!]]'' by the Swedish director [[Kjell Grede]], inspired by Krøyer's famous painting.<ref name="QvistBagh2000">{{cite book|last1=Qvist|first1=Per Olov|last2=Bagh|first2=Peter von|title=Guide to the Cinema of Sweden and Finland|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rnpoR8VMUNoC&pg=PA78|year=2000|publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group|isbn=978-0-313-30377-7|page=78}}</ref>
In 2012, the film ''[[The Passion of Marie]]'', directed by [[Bille August]], covered Marie's increasingly difficult relationship with her husband P.S. Krøyer. The film is based on the book ''Balladen om Marie'' by Anastassia Arnold.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kino.dk/film/m/ma/marie-kroeyer|title=Marie Krøyer|publisher=Kino.dk|language=Danish|accessdate=15 October 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Arnold|first=Anastassia|title=Balladen om Marie: en biografi om Marie Krøyer|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=w0xockgw4uQC|year=2010|publisher=Rosinante|isbn=978-87-638-1229-0}}</ref> [[File:P.S. Krøyer - Summer evening on Skagen's Beach. Anna Ancher and Marie Krøyer walking together. - Google Art Project.jpg|thumbnail|350px|''[[Summer Evening on Skagen's Southern Beach]]'', one of the artist's most cherished images, [[P.S. Krøyer]], 1893]]
==Exhibitions==
There have been a number of exhibitions of the Skagen Painters in recent years. In 2008, the [[Arken Museum of Modern Art]] in Copenhagen presented "The Skagen Painters — In a New Light", contrasting the paintings depicting the artists with those of the fishermen.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.arken.dk/content/us/art/exhibitions/past_exhibitions/2008|title=Past Exhibitions: 2008|publisher=Arken|accessdate=16 August 2014 |language=}}</ref> In 2011, the [[Hirschsprung Collection|Hirschsprung Museum]] in Copenhagen succeeded in arranging the largest exhibition of Krøyer's work titled : "Krøyer—i internationalt lys" (Krøyer—in international light), with works from museums and private collections in France, Germany, the United States and Scandinavia.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aok.dk/udstilling/den-hidtil-stoerste-kroeyer-udstilling-aabner-i-koebenhavn#what:Udstilling|title=Den hidtil største Krøyer-udstilling åbner i København|publisher=AOK|date=15 November 2011|accessdate=16 August 2014 |language=}}</ref> The [[National Museum of Women in the Arts]] in Washington, D.C. presented "A World Apart: Anna Ancher and the Skagen Art Colony" in 2013. It was the largest exhibition of Anna Ancher's paintings ever held in the United States.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nmwa.org/exhibitions/world-apart|title=A World Apart|publisher=National Museum of Women in the Arts|accessdate=16 August 2014 |language=}}</ref> In 2014, Skagens Museum, which frequently presents new aspects of the work of the Skagen Painters, concentrated its efforts on "Laurits Tuxen—colour, countryside and crown", presenting many works held in private collections illustrating the artist's involvement in establishing Kunstnernes Studieskole (The Artists' School of Study) in Copenhagen as well as his work as a court painter.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.skagensmuseum.dk/en/exhibitions/|title=Laurits Tuxen — colour, countryside and crown: Skagens Museum - 3 May - 14. September 2014 |publisher=Skagens Museum |accessdate=16 August 2014 |language=}}</ref>
A major exhibition of paintings by the Skagen Painters titled ''Michael Ancher – P.S. Krøyer: Venner og Rivaler'' (Friends and Rivals) is to be held at [[Arken Museum of Modern Art|Arken]], Copenhagen from 27 September 2014 to 12 April 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.arken.dk/content/dk/kunst/udstillinger/kommende_udstillinger|title=Kommende udstillinger|publisher=Arken|accessdate=28 August 2014 |language=Danish}}</ref>

[[Image:Curveasy.jpg|thumb|200 px|right| ]] A '''slide chart''' is a hand-held device, usually of paper, cardboard, or plastic, for conducting simple calculations or looking up information. A circular slide chart is sometimes referred to as a wheel chart or [[volvelle]].
Unlike other hand-held mechanical calculating devices such as [[slide rules]] and [[addiator]]s, which have been replaced by electronic calculators and computer software, wheel charts and slide charts have survived to the present time. There are a number of companies who design and manufacture these devices.
Unlike the general-purpose mechanical calculators, slide charts are usually devoted to carrying out a particular specialized calculation, or displaying information on a single product or a particular process. For example, the "CurveEasy" wheel chart displays information related to spherical geometry calculations and the Prestolog calculator is used for cost/profit calculations. Another example of a wheel chart is the [[planisphere]], which shows the location of stars in the sky for a given location, date, and time.
Slide charts are often associated with particular sports, political campaigns or commercial companies. For example, a pharmaceutical company may create wheel charts printed with their company name and product information for distribution to medical practitioners.
Slide charts are common collectables.
==References== * ''Reinventing the Wheel'', [[Jessica Helfand]], Princeton Architectural Press, 2002. ({{ISBN|978-1-56898-596-1}})
==See also== * The [[E6B]] aviation flight computing device, still in regular use
==External links== * [https://archive.is/20121216154456/http://www.tinajuliecordon.webspace.virginmedia.com/Slide%20Rules/SlideCharts.html Slide Chart Examples]

A '''strophe''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|s|t|r|oʊ|f|iː}}) is a poetic term originally referring to the first part of the [[ode]] in [[Ancient Greek tragedy]], followed by the [[antistrophe]] and [[epode]]. The term has been extended to also mean a structural division of a poem containing [[stanza]]s of varying line length. Strophic poetry is to be contrasted with poems composed line-by-line non-stanzaically, such as Greek [[Epic poetry|epic poems]] or English [[blank verse]], to which the term ''[[stichic]]'' applies.
In its original Greek setting, "strophe, antistrophe and epode were a kind of [[stanza]] framed only for the music," as [[John Milton]] wrote in the preface to ''[[Samson Agonistes]]'', with the strophe chanted by a [[Greek chorus]] as it moved from right to left across the scene.
==Etymology== Strophe (from [[Ancient Greek|Greek]] [[wikt:στροφή|στροφή]], "turn, bend, twist") is a concept in [[poetry|versification]] which properly means a turn, as from one [[Foot (prosody)|foot]] to another, or from one side of a chorus to the other.
==Poetic structure== In a more general sense, the strophe is a pair of [[stanza]]s of alternating form on which the structure of a given poem is based, with the strophe usually being identical with the stanza in modern poetry and its arrangement and recurrence of rhymes giving it its character. But the Greeks called a combination of verse-periods a system, giving the name "strophe" to such a system only when it was repeated once or more in unmodified form.
A simple form of Greek strophe is the Sapphic strophe. Like all Greek verse, it is composed of alternating long and short syllables (symbolized by '''—''' for long, '''u''' for short and '''x''' for either long or short) in this case arranged in the following manner:<ref>William S. Annis. Introduction to Greek Meter. Aoidoi.org January 2006. [http://www.aoidoi.org/articles/meter/intro.pdf. Page 11.]</ref>
'''— u — x — u u — u — —'''
'''— u — x — u u — u — —'''
'''— u — x — u u — u — x — u u — —'''
Far more complex forms are found in the odes of [[Pindar]] and the choral sections of [[Greek drama]].
In choral poetry, it is common to find the strophe followed by a metrically identical [[antistrophe]], which may – in Pindar and other [[epinician]] poets – be followed in turn by a metrically dissimilar [[epode]],<ref>Edwin D. Floyd. "Some more or less technical observations on Greek rhythm." class material for University of Pittsburgh: Classics 1130. http://www.pitt.edu/~edfloyd/Class1130/strophe.html accessed January 6, 2015.</ref> creating an ''AAB'' form.
==Origins and development== It is said that [[Archilochus of Paros|Archilochus]] first created the strophe by binding together systems of two or three lines. But it was the [[Greece|Greek]] ode-writers who introduced the practice of strophe-writing on a large scale, and the art was attributed to [[Stesichorus]], although it is likely that earlier poets were acquainted with it. The arrangement of an [[ode]] in a splendid and consistent artifice of strophe, [[antistrophe]] and [[epode]] was carried to its height by [[Pindar]].
==Variant forms== With the development of Greek [[Meter (poetry)|prosody]], various peculiar strophe-forms came into general acceptance, and were made celebrated by the frequency with which leading poets employed them. Among these were the ''Sapphic,'' the ''Elegiac,'' the ''Alcaic,'' and the ''Asclepiadean'' strophe, all of them prominent in Greek and Latin verse. The briefest and the most ancient strophe is the ''dactylic distych,'' which consists of two verses of the same class of rhythm, the second producing a melodic counterpart to the first.
==Reproductions== The forms in modern English verse which reproduce most exactly the impression aimed at by the ancient odestrophe are the elaborate rhymed stanzas of such poems as [[John Keats|Keats]]' ''[[wikisource:Ode to a Nightingale|Ode to a Nightingale]]'' or [[Matthew Arnold]]'s ''[[wikisource:The Scholar-Gipsy|The Scholar-Gipsy]]''.
A strophic form of poetry called [[Muwashshah]] developed in [[Andalucia]] as early as the 9th century C.E, which then spread to North Africa and the Middle East. Muwashshah was typically in classical Arabic, with the refrain sometimes in the local dialect.
==Contemporary usage== The term strophe is used in modern and post-modern criticism, to indicate "long non-isomorphic units".<ref>Page 1360, Entry 'STROPHE', The Princeton Encyclopedia of Poetry and Poetics: Fourth Edition, edited by Stephen Cushman, Clare Cavanagh, Jahan Ramazani, Paul Rouzer</ref> The term "stanza [is used] for more regular ones" (ibid). This appropriation of the ancient term is useful, as contemporary poetry is a frequent turns (the original meaning of Strophe), and it avoids relying upon the invention of new terminology such as 'word clumps'.
==See also== * [[Strophic form]]

{{italic title}} [[Image:BuscotParkSaloonView.jpg|thumb|right|250px|View of the Saloon at Buscot Park showing two of the major panels – ''The Garden Court'' and ''The Rose Bower'' – in their context between the adjoining panels]] '''''The Legend of Briar Rose''''' is the title of a series of paintings by the [[Pre-Raphaelite]] artist [[Edward Burne-Jones]] which were completed between 1885 and 1890. The four original paintings – '''''The Briar Wood''''', '''''The Council Chamber''''', '''''The Garden Court''''' and '''''The Rose Bower''''' – and an additional ten adjoining panels, are located at [[Buscot Park]] in [[Oxfordshire]], [[England]]. The four major panels were first exhibited at Agnew's Gallery in [[Bond Street]], [[London]] in 1890. They were acquired by [[Alexander Henderson, 1st Baron Faringdon|Alexander Henderson]], later to become the Lord Faringdon, for Buscot Park. When Burne-Jones visited the house and saw the paintings in their new setting he decided to extend the frames of each of the four paintings and fill in the gaps with joining panels which continued the rose motif from the main paintings. ==Major panels== Each major panel measures 49 by 98¼ inches but the ten joining panels vary in width. The paintings do not tell a sequential story but record the same moment in each location. ===''The Briar Wood''=== [[Image:Briar Wood Buscot Park.jpg|thumb|right|250px|''The Briar Wood'',]] The painting depicts the discovery of the sleeping soldiers by a Knight. In their slumber they have become completed entwined by the barbed thorns of the [[Rosa rubiginosa|Briar rose]]. Running beneath each of the major panels is an inscription of a poem by [[William Morris]], under ''The Briar Wood'' the inscription reads:
"The fateful slumber floats and flows
About the tangle of the rose;
But lo! the fated hand and heart
To rend the slumberous curse apart!" [http://www.victorianartinbritain.co.uk/gallery/buscot_park.htm Buscot Park, Faringdon, Oxfordshire. The Home of The Briar Rose. The Most Complete Cycle of Paintings by Edward Burne-Jones] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070504110126/http://www.victorianartinbritain.co.uk/gallery/buscot_park.htm |date=2007-05-04 }} at Victorian Art in Britain.
===''The Council Chamber''=== [[Image:The Council Chamber Buscot Park.jpg|thumb|left|250px|''The Council Chamber'']] The painting shows the scene in the Council chamber. The members of the council sleep, as does the King who is slumped on his throne. Under the draped curtains and through the window further soldiers can be seen sleeping. Under ''The Council Chamber'', the inscription reads:
"The threat of war, the hope of peace,
The Kingdoms peril and increase
Sleep on, and bide the latter day
When Fate shall take her chain away."
===''The Garden Court''=== [[Image:The Garden Court Buscot Park.jpg|thumb|right|250px|''The Garden Court'']] The painting shows the weavers having fallen asleep at their [[loom]]. The walls of the castle form the backdrop to the painting as do arches of roses. Under ''The Garden Court'', the inscription reads:
"The maiden pleasance of the land
Knoweth no stir of voice or hand,
No cup the sleeping waters fill,
The restless shuttle lieth still."
===''The Rose Bower''=== [[Image:The Rose Bower Buscot Park.jpg|thumb|left|250px|''The Rose Bower'']] The sleeping beauty lies on her bed surrounded by her slumbering attendants. The rose is seen encircling the drapery in the background Under ''The Rose Bower'', the inscription reads:
Here lies the hoarded love, the key
To all the treasure that shall be;
Come fated hand the gift to take
And smite this sleeping world awake."
==Subject== The paintings depict a moment in the story of "[[Sleeping Beauty]]", the title of the series coming from the version presented by the [[Brothers Grimm]] in their collection of 1812.Jacob and Wilheim Grimm, ''Grimms' Fairy Tales'', [http://www.surlalunefairytales.com/sleepingbeauty/stories/littlebriarose.html "Little Briar-Rose"] ==Related works== Burne-Jones created two other series of paintings on the same subject.[http://www.buscot-park.com/gallery/pic_035.html Paintings at Buscot page 3] *The [[Small Briar Rose series|''Small Briar Rose'' series]] was completed before the Buscot Park series. All three paintings – ''The Briar Wood, The Council Chamber, The Rose Bower'' – are now in the [[Ponce Museum of Art|Museo de Arte de Ponce]], Puerto Rico. *The [[Third Briar Rose series]] was completed after the Buscot Park series. The three paintings have been split between three collections. ''The Garden Court'' is in [[Bristol City Museum and Art Gallery]], ''The Council Chamber'' is in the [[Delaware Art Museum]], Wilmington and ''The Rose Bower'' is in the [[Hugh Lane Municipal Gallery|Hugh Lane Gallery of Modern Art]], Dublin. ==References== ==External links== *[http://www.buscot-park.com/gallery/pic_035.html ''The Legend of Briar Rose'' at Buscot Park] *[http://libmma.contentdm.oclc.org/cdm/ref/collection/p15324coll10/id/67586 ''Edward Burne-Jones, Victorian artist-dreamer''], fully digitized text from The Metropolitan Museum of Art libraries {{Edward Burne-Jones}} {{Sleeping Beauty}} {{Pre-Raphaelite Brotherhood}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Legend Of Briar Rose}} [[Category:Paintings by Edward Burne-Jones]] [[Category:Works based on Sleeping Beauty]] [[Category:Paintings in South East England]] [[Category:Painting series]] [[Category:Art based on fairy tales]]

Art alone
Enduring stays to us;
The Bust outlasts the throne,—
The Coin, Tiberius" | website = {{url|http://www.plasticclub.org}} | remarks = | formerly = | footnotes = }} '''The Plastic Club''' is an arts organization located in [[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania]]. Founded in 1897, the Plastic Club is one of the oldest art clubs in the United States. It is located on the 200 block of Camac Street, the "Little Street of Clubs" that was a cultural destination in the early 1900s.{{Cite web|url=http://hiddencityphila.org/2014/03/little-clubs-on-a-wooden-street/|title=Little Clubs On A Wooden Street {{!}} Hidden City Philadelphia|website=hiddencityphila.org|access-date=2016-03-04}} Since 1991, the club's membership also includes men. ==History== The Plastic Club was founded by art educator [[Emily Sartain]]. It was founded as an arts organization for women to promote collaboration and members' works, partly in response to the [[Philadelphia Sketch Club]], an exclusively male arts club.{{Cite journal|last=Van Hook|first=Bailey|date=2009-01-01|title=The Early Career of Violet Oakley, Illustrator|jstor=40605220|journal=Woman's Art Journal|volume=30|issue=1|pages=29–38}} The first President was the etcher [[Blanche Dillaye]].{{cite book|last1=Croly|first1=Jane Cunningham|title=The History of the Women's Club Movement in America|date=1898|publisher=Henry G. Allen & Co.|location=New York|page=1049|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OFJKn1HaKiAC&dq=%22plastic%20club%22&pg=PA1049#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=4 March 2016}} The motto of the club was taken from a poem by [[Theophile Gautier]]: {{blockquote|All passes. Art alone
Enduring stays to us;
The Bust outlasts the throne,—
The Coin, Tiberius{{cite book|last1=Ruedig|first1=Reagan Baydoun|title=The Plastic Club of Philadelphia: A Site Management Study and Building Analysis|date=2007|page=4|url=http://www.plasticclub.org/Thesis-Revised.pdf}}}} [[File:Womendesignersof00ston 0053.jpg|left|thumb|430x430px|Insignia of The Plastics Club]] The Plastic Club insignia was designed by [[Elisabeth Hallowell Saunders|Elisabeth M. Halloway]].{{Cite book|url=https://archive.org/details/womendesignersof00ston/page/36?q=Elisabeth+M.+Hallowell|title=Women designers of book-plates|last=Stone|first=Wilbur Macey|publisher=Randolph R. Beam|year=1902|isbn=|location=|pages=36|lccn=21001867}} The club offered art classes, social events, and exhibitions. Its annual masquerade party was called "the Rabbit."[https://hsp.org/sites/default/files/legacy_files/migrated/findingaid3106plasticclub.pdf ''The Plastic Club.''] The Historical Society of Pennsylvania. Retrieved March 4, 2014.{{cite book|author1=Jill P. May|author2=Robert E. May|author3=Howard Pyle|title=Howard Pyle: Imagining an American School of Art|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xTzraRXV7OMC&pg=PA89|year=2011|publisher=University of Illinois Press|page=89|isbn=978-0-252-03626-2}} Early members included [[Elenore Abbott|Elenore Plaisted Abbott]], Paula Himmelsbach Balano, [[Cecilia Beaux]], [[Fern Coppedge]], [[Elizabeth Shippen Green]], [[Charlotte Harding]], [[Frances Tipton Hunter]], [[Violet Oakley]], [[Emily Sartain|Emily]] and Harriet Sartain, [[Jessie Willcox Smith]], and [[Alice Barber Stephens]], many of whom had been students of [[Howard Pyle]]. When the fall exhibition was held in 1898, the works of Pyle's former students—[[Elizabeth Fearne Bonsall]], Elizabeth Shippen Green, Jessie Willcox Smith, Charlotte Harding, Violet Oakley, and Angela De Cora—were singled out. In 1918, the club was involved in the founding of the Philadelphia School of Occupational Therapy,{{Cite book|url=http://hdl.handle.net/2027/loc.ark:/13960/t3ws95r99|title=Philadelphia in the world war, 1914-1919.|date=1922-01-01|publisher=New York :}} reflecting the connection between [[occupational therapy]] and the [[Arts and Crafts movement]] in the United States between the [[American Civil War|Civil War]] and [[World War I]].Peloquin, S. (2005). The 2005 Eleanor Clarke Slagle Lecture-Embracing our methods, reclaiming our heart. ''American Journal of Occupational Therapy, 59'', 611–625 In 1991 the organization opened its membership to include men. During the 1990s the club also sought to attract art students, offering free membership to two recent graduates a year. The Plastic Club building at 247 South Camac Street was added to the Philadelphia Register of Historic Places in 1962.{{cite book|last1=Ruedig|first1=Reagan Baydoun|title=The Plastic Club of Philadelphia: A Site Management Study and Building Analysis|date=2007|page=9|url=http://www.plasticclub.org/Thesis-Revised.pdf}} ==Noted past members== The Plastic Club has identified the following noted past members:{{cite web | url=http://www.plasticclub.org/pastnote.html | title=Noted Past Members | publisher=The Plastic Club | accessdate=March 26, 2015 }} {{Div col}} * [[Elenore Abbott|Elenore Plaisted Abbott]] * [[Paula Himmelsbach Balano]] * [[Cecilia Beaux]] * [[Fern Coppedge|Fern T. Coppedge]] * [[Blanche Dillaye]] * [[Grace Drayton|Grace Gebbie Wiederseim Drayton]] * [[Beatrice Fenton]] * [[Beatrice Fox]] * [[Elizabeth Shippen Green]] * [[Violet Oakley]] * [[Esther Richards]] * [[Harriet Sartain]] * [[Emily Sartain]] * [[Jessie Willcox Smith]] * [[Wuanita Smith]] * [[Alice Barber Stephens]] * [[Alice Kent Stoddard]] * [[Beatrice Pastorius Turner]] {{cite web|url=http://www.2015rrcus.org/ladies-of-newport.html |title=Ladies of Newport |publisher=2015rrcus.org |date=2014-02-03 |accessdate=2016-03-03}} * [[Sarah Stilwell Weber]] {{Div col end}} Painter [[Amy Otis]] was also a member of the Club.{{cite book|author=Albert Nelson Marquis|title=Who's who in New England: A Biographical Dictionary of Leading Living Men and Women of the States of Maine, New Hampshire, Vermont, Massachusetts, Rhode Island and Connecticut|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5jk1AAAAIAAJ&pg=PA807|year=1915|publisher=A.N. Marquis & Company|pages=807–}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Further reading== * {{cite book|author1=Plastic Club|author2=Violet Oakley|author3=Jessie Willcox Smith, Elizabeth Shippen Green|title=The Plastic Club Catalogue: Exhibition of Work by Violet Oakley, Jessie Willcox Smith, Elizabeth Shippen Green|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WRFSHQAACAAJ|year=1902|publisher=Plastic Club|location=Philadelphia}} ==External links== * {{official website|http://www.plasticclub.org}} * [https://books.google.com/books?id=4-E-AAAAYAAJ&dq=blanche%20dillaye&pg=PA446#v=onepage&q&f=false Finding Aid for The Plastic Club Records, 1888-2007], [[The Historical Society of Pennsylvania]]. {{DEFAULTSORT:Plastic Club}} [[Category:Feminist art organizations]] [[Category:Women's organizations based in the United States]] [[Category:Women's clubs in the United States]] [[Category:Arts organizations based in Pennsylvania]] [[Category:Organizations based in Philadelphia]] [[Category:Arts organizations established in the 1890s]] [[Category:Organizations established in 1897]] [[Category:1897 establishments in Pennsylvania]] {{Woman's club movement}} {{Authority control}}

{{orphan|date=April 2018}} A '''vernacular painting in China''' is a realistic, folk depiction of scenes from everyday domestic life.
The term is often applied to paintings that were frequently displayed in [[Qing dynasty|High Qing China]] during the New Year and birthdays.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Chang|first=Michael G.|date=2010|title=Pictures for Use and Pleasure: Vernacular Painting in High Qing China (review)|url=https://muse.jhu.edu/article/479044|journal=China Review International|language=en|volume=17|issue=3|pages=299–303|doi=10.1353/cri.2010.0072|issn=1527-9367}}</ref> In his 2010 book ''Pictures for Use and Pleasure'', art historian [[James Cahill (art historian)|James Cahill]] defines the term as "a great body of painting, created over the centuries by studio artists working in the cities, artists who produced pictures as required for diverse everyday domestic and other uses."<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title=Pictures for use and pleasure : vernacular painting in high Qing China|last=Cahill|first=James|date=2010|publisher=University of California Press|isbn=9780520258570|location=Berkeley|oclc=449860109}}</ref>{{Rp|3}} These paintings were often created on silk,<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RhmaCgAAQBAJ&pg=PA274|title=The Qing Dynasty and Traditional Chinese Culture|last=Smith|first=Richard J.|date=2015|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield|isbn=9781442221949|location=|pages=274|language=en}}</ref> and pieces created for women were known for depicting "a range of topics not dealt with in literati painting."<ref>{{Cite book|title=A Companion to Chinese Art|last=Murck|first=Alfreda|date=2015|publisher=John Wiley & Sons, Inc.|isbn=9781118885215|editor-last=Powers|editor-first=rtin J.|pages=455–473|language=en|doi=10.1002/9781118885215.ch22|editor-last2=Tsiang|editor-first2=Katherine R.|chapter = Words in Chinese Painting}}</ref>
The paintings revealed Chinese life and the workings of Chinese society, Vernacular paintings were frequently created by master artists with only small prestige in city studios. They also differed from other paintings made during the era in that they were seen as functional and frequently lacked inscriptions,<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HWu-CgAAQBAJ&pg=PT872|title=A Companion to Chinese Art|last=Powers|first=Martin J.|last2=Tsiang|first2=Katherine R.|date=2015|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|isbn=9781118885208|language=en}}</ref> whereas the culture of the time "professed to despise functionalism."<ref name=":0" />{{Rp|3-4}} As Chinese connoiseurs preferred paintings where the artist's brushwork skill, as well as their feelings and temperament, showed in the art, these paintings were seen as lesser in value and considered to be irrelevant.<ref name=":0" /> Some of the elements in Vernacular Paintings, such as the use of paintings for celebrations and life events such as weddings and birthdays, would later be co-opted by some of the more elite art styles such as Shanghai painting.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pESTBQAAQBAJ&pg=PA54|title=Art Worlds: Artists, Images, and Audiences in Late Nineteenth-Century Shanghai|last=Wue|first=Roberta|date=2014|publisher=Hong Kong University Press|isbn=9789888208463|location=|pages=54|language=en}}</ref>

{{Primary sources|date=May 2008}} '''Youth in Arts''' is a [[non-profit]] organization that provides [[visual art|visual]] and [[performing arts]] instruction to public and private school students and enriches the community with cultural events. Youth in Arts has been providing [[Arts in education|arts education]] to [[students]] in the [[San Francisco]] [[Bay Area]] since 1970.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.youthinarts.org/|title=Youth In Arts San Rafael|publisher=Youthinarts.org|accessdate=17 February 2015}}</ref> It is based in [[San Rafael, California|San Rafael]], Ca. The Artists in Schools program brings artists into classrooms to teach visual and performing arts in extended residencies or shorter workshop programs and also provides training for teachers and parents in supporting students' learning and development through the arts.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.marinmagazine.com/Marin-Magazine/June-2008/Art-for-Kids-Sake/|title=Art for Kids' Sake|publisher=Marinmagazine.com|accessdate=17 February 2015}}</ref>
Youth in Arts also houses the only children's art gallery in the Northern Bay Area. Youth in Arts reaches over 30,000 youth annually. Youth in Arts creates interactive public art works at the Marin County Fair.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.marinij.com/opinion/ci_15424234|title=Marin Voice: Fair brings world a little closer|publisher=Marinij.com|accessdate=17 February 2015}}</ref> During July 2013, Youth in Arts worked with over 600 youth and professional artists to create the world's biggest pop up book spanning 48' long and 6' high.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.marinij.com/marinnews/ci_23621279/worlds-biggest-pop-up-book-displayed-at-marin|title=World's biggest pop-up book displayed at Marin County Fair|publisher=Marinij.com|accessdate=17 February 2015}}</ref>
An independent evaluation of the Artists in Schools program, funded by a grant from the [[California Arts Council]], found that three-quarters of the students participating showed a more positive attitude toward learning in an arts-inclusive classroom.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2004/03/05/NBGGC58DOH1.DTL|title=Fade to red / Program that brings arts to schools is running out of cash|work=SFGate|accessdate=17 February 2015}}</ref> Some schools pay Youth in Arts for programming. The agency also fundraises to offset costs and to provide free programs to schools that cannot afford to pay.
In addition to the Artists in Schools program, Youth in Arts Presents offers live performances to thousands of local students through Theater Shows and Assemblies; VSA arts and "Arts Unite Us"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.marinscope.com/mill_valley_herald/news/article_76b4ccb0-020f-533a-be28-1f6ce5782295.html|title=Special Education and theater students create one-act play|work=Marinscope Community Newspapers|accessdate=17 February 2015}}</ref> provide tailored programs to special needs students and bring together students of differing abilities through the arts and 'Til Dawn is an award-winning teen a cappella program for advanced young vocalists.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.marinmagazine.com/Marin-Magazine/May-2010/Something-to-Sing-About/|title=Something to Sing About|publisher=Marinmagazine.com|accessdate=17 February 2015}}</ref>
Youth in Arts founded the Italian Street Painting Festival in downtown San Rafael and ran that event for 17 years, that event is now being continued by a separate organization, Italian Street Painting Marin.

page.title: Zhong Kui the Demon Queller with Five Bats

revision.text:
{{italic title}} [[File:Zhong Kui the Demon Queller with Five Bats.jpg|thumb|400px|The painting ''Zhong Kui the Demon Queller with Five Bats'' from the [[Ming dynasty]]]]
'''''Zhong Kui the Demon Queller with Five Bats''''' is a popular [[Chinese painting]] featuring the [[Chinese mythology|Chinese mythological]] spirit [[Zhong Kui]]. It originates from the [[Ming dynasty]] (1368–1644).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://gr.pinterest.com/pin/349732727289844156/|title=人物|publisher=Pinterest}}</ref> A possible painter for this artwork is [[Wu Wei (painter)|Wu Wei]]. The painting is held in the [[Ashmolean Museum]] in [[England]].<ref name="auto">{{cite web|url=http://www.jameelcentre.ashmolean.org/collection/6980/9855/0/all/per_page/25/offset/0/sort_by/seqn./object/11589|title=Ashmolean − Eastern Art Online, Yousef Jameel Centre for Islamic and Asian Art|publisher=Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford}}</ref>
==Description== The picture features Zhong Kui, accompanied by two of his demon followers. The demons are holding a vase and Zhong Kui holds a scepter while looking up at five [[Bat|bats]] flying in the sky. In Chinese symbolism, the five bats represent five blessings: health, longevity, virtue, wealth, and a graceful death. In the background is a forested mountain surrounded by a heavy mist.<ref name="auto"/>
